div.head: To make Cloth whiche hath lo≈øt his colour, to returne vnto his fir≈øt e≈øtate agayne.
div.p: TAKE OF VNQVENched lyme two ounces, of Oake a≈øhes two ounces, of cleare water two pound. Then meddle theÃÑ well all together, and ≈øo let them re≈øt one quarter of an houre, and then doe clarifie that water, and therewith wa≈øh your cloth, and it will returne vnto his fir≈øt colour, and waxe fayre agayne as before.

div.head: ¬∂ To wa≈øh a ≈øcarlet which is grea≈øie.
div.p: Take of whyte tarter wel and finely beaten, foure ounces: then boyle it in two pound of fayre water, till the thyrde part be con≈øumed: then take it from the fyre, and let it coole, and then ≈øtrayne it through a linnen cloth, and when ye will v≈øe thereof, make it then milke warme, and wa≈øh therewith your cloth. Then hang it to drye, and you ≈øhall ≈øee it fayre, and returne to his fir≈øt e≈øtate and coloure agayne.

div.head: ¬∂ To make all colours of ≈øilkes which be ≈øtaynde, to come to their fir≈øt colour againe.
div.p:
Fyr≈øt take one ounce of vnquenched lyme, and of the a≈øhes of a vyne one ounce, al≈øo of a≈øhes of an Oake one ouÃÑce and a halfe. Put all the≈øe into a ba≈øen of cleare water, and meddle them all well togither, then heate them a little ouer
the fyre, and when it is warme, take it of the fyre, and let it clarifie a while, ≈øo done, then take a ≈øponge and wa≈øh your ≈øtaynie ≈øpottes therewith, and ≈øee that ye weat no other place, but the ≈øpotty places only, and ≈øo they wil be well agayne.

div.head: ¬∂ To make a ≈øope to take forth greace or other ≈øpoties what≈øoeuer they be.
div.p: Take one pound of roche Allum burnd and made into a fyne poulder. Al≈øo take of the rootes cald flames of Florence (≈øo calde in Dutche) halfe a pound: then beate it in to a pouder. Then take a new layde egge, & of white ≈øope two pound and a halfe, then blend your pouder, and your egge and ≈øope altogether well, and thereof make pellots or bals, and if one egge be not ≈øufficient, then take ii. or ≈øo much as ≈øhall ≈øuffice to make your ≈øayd pa≈øte withal, and when ye ≈øhall haue occa≈øion to take forth anye ≈øpotte, take fir≈øt of commen water and wa≈øh your ≈øpots on both ≈øides withal warme, then take of the ≈øayd pellots, and rubbe al ouer the ≈øpottes in the cloth, ≈øo done: then wa≈øhe out the filth with fayre cleare water, and if there remayne ≈øome part and be not all cleane, wa≈øh it agayne as afore is meÃÑ tioned, till it be all cleane, and ≈øo ≈øhall ye haue it as fayre as before.

div.head: ¬∂ Another good way to take forth ≈øpots of greace out of any woollen or linnen.
div.p:
Take fir≈øt a little fayre water, all to weate and rubbe therewith the ≈øayd greace ≈øpottes. Then take a quantity of walkars claye, called Fullars earth, and rubbe a little therewith your ≈øpottes all ouer. Then rubbe and chafe
your cloth one vppon another, ≈øo done, take a ≈øyluer ≈øpone or ≈øuch like thing, and ≈øcrape out the ≈øayde filthie water and greace, and if then it bee not all cleane foorth, doe ≈øo agayne as before is mentioned, and then take a little warme water, and all to weate the ≈øayde place therwith, ≈øo done, Then wring and ≈øcrape it foorth as the other afore. Being then cleane, let it be dryde and it will be well.

div.head: ¬∂ To take away all ≈øpottes on coulered Clothes, be they linnen or woollen
div.p: If there chaunce by fortune, to fall a droppe of ynke, or any other ≈øtayne, vppon any cloth dyed or coloured, or being cleane whyte, woollen or linnen. Ye ≈øhall doe as hereafter followeth, that is: take of the iuyce of rawe Lemmons, or the iuyce of a great Orange Apple, which hath a hard pill or ≈økinne, which the Italions call Pommes Dadam. Or if ye will take onlye the egar or ≈øharpe iuyce which is in the pouncitron, and ≈øtrayne it foorth thereof, and with the iuyce yee ≈øhall all to rubbe and chaufe the ≈øayde ≈øpottye places, and then wa≈øh it with luke warme water, and ≈øo then ≈øcrape out all the filth thereof, with ≈øome ≈øpoone as afore≈øayde, or wring it cleane foorth with your handes. If at the fir≈øte time peraduenture it bee not cleane, v≈øe it likewi≈øe agayne the ≈øeconde tyme, as before, and ≈øo your cloth will come vnto as good e≈øtate as at the fyr≈øte, nor this ≈øhall not hurte anye coloure thereof.

div.head: ¬∂ Another good way to make cleane ≈øpottes of greace, out of all woollen clothes.
div.p:
Take an hearbe called wood ≈øorrel, or ≈øtubwort, which is green, & groweth in woods, in bu≈øhes & ≈øtubs of old trees,
and hath three ≈ømall leaues lyke a hart, it ta≈øteth ≈øharpe lyke other ≈øorrell. Which hearbe ye ≈øhall di≈øtill in a lymbee, and ≈øo re≈øerue the di≈øtild water in a gla≈ø≈øe very clo≈øe, and when you neede to take foorth any ≈øpotte of greace, then take of the di≈øtylde water, and rubbe therewith all ouer the ≈øayd ≈øpottes. Then chafe your cloth one vppon another: ≈øo done, take a ≈øpoone, or ≈øome other lyke thing, and take away the ≈øayd filthie water therewith. Then if it be not all cleane, doe it likewi≈øe agayne as before, with the di≈øtilde water warmed, and then yee ≈øhall ≈øee it will doe well, and ≈øhewe fayre and cleare as it was at the fir≈øte.

div.head: Another good way to take out ≈øpottes out of clothes with a lye.
div.p: Take three pintes of water, and put therein halfe a pounde of pot a≈øhes, and ≈øtirre it well altogether. Let it ≈øo ≈øtande the ≈øpace of foure dayes, but yee mu≈øt in euerye daye ≈øtirre it three or foure times. So done, poure foorth the cleare water from the a≈øhes, and put of galles therin, then it will waxe a greene: but if ye wil haue it a blacke, then put a little ≈øoote to ≈øoke in fayre water, and put that black water therein. With this warmed, ye maye wa≈øhe your ≈øpottie places in any place of your clothes, & it will take it forth fayre and cleane.

div.head: To perfume clothes.
div.p:
Take a violl of Ro≈øe-water, in the which ye ≈øhall put eyghteene or twentie graynes of Mu≈øke, and Ciuet, with a little of Ambergreace, then ≈øet all on the fyre, and wheÃÑ it begins to waxe warme, take it from the fyre, and let it coole, and ≈øtoppe it clo≈øe the ≈øpace of two dayes, and when ye will perfume your clothes therewith. Set it on the fyre agayne, and being warme, holde your clothes ouer
it, and ≈øo it ≈øhal receiue the fume.

div.head: To take out ≈øpottes out of gownes and clothes.
div.p: Take the rootes of LimonioÃÑ, cald in Latine, in Engli≈øh I take it to be the wild Bete. Take the rootes, and ≈øeeth them in water, and with the ≈øame water, wa≈øh the ≈øpotty places in your gownes or other garments, and it will be cleane.

div.head: To make a ≈øope to take out ≈øpottes of oyle and of greace.
div.p: Take of good ≈øcowring ≈øope, and mixe it finely with the ≈øyfted a≈øhes of a vyne, of eche in like portion, theÃÑ put therevnto a quantitie of the powder of burnt allum, and al≈øo of the lies of wyne, beaten into a fine pouder, and put it therevnto, then mixe and incorporate all the≈øe well together, then make thereof ≈øquare brickes, or round bals, and when yee ≈øhall haue neede to occupye thereof, then take of warme water, and rubbe and chafe all ouer your ≈øpottye places, and then rubbe thereon with your ≈øope ball, if then it be not all cleane, then mu≈øt ye take your warme water agayne, and rubbe and chaffe it, as yee did before, and then your ≈øope, and ≈øo at length ye ≈øhal haue it cleane forth.

div.head: A very good way to take out ≈øpottes of oyle out of clothes.
div.p:
Fyr≈øt ye ≈øhal take of the oyle of tartar, and rubbe therwith on the ≈øpotty places, and then ≈øcrape it away incontinent agayn, then ye ≈øhall wa≈øh it well with luke warme water, and three or foure times with colde water, ≈øo then
wring it foorth, and ≈øee if all the ≈øpots be cleane out, if not, wa≈øh it agayne, ≈øo long as you did before, and ≈øo the cloth ≈øhal be as fayre as it was when it was new, or before any ≈øpots came on it. There is al≈øo another way, for to take forth ≈øpots with this cyle of Tartar, but becau≈øe I haue not the true knowledge thereof, I wil not here expre≈ø≈øe it.

div.head: ¬∂ A ≈øope water to take out all ≈øpots.
div.p: Al≈øo, ≈øome doe v≈øe to take the water wherein ≈øtrawberries had bene ≈øodde, and with that water ye ≈øhal wete and ≈øoke the ≈øpottye places, then take fayre water, and wa≈øhe out all the filth thereof, ≈øo done: take and hang it in the ≈øonne to drye, and it will be ≈øo cleane as before it was.

div.head: A way to take out yron moles, out of all linnen cloth.
div.p: Take and wring forth ≈øo much of the iuice of the ≈øowre≈øt Orange, or Limon that ye can get, then take of the ≈øame iuyce, and rubbe the place of the yron moll therwith ≈øo let it dry, and euer as it dryeth in, rubbe it ouer again, thus doe often, and euer as you haue wet it, let it re≈øt and drie in the ≈øunne, and at the length ye ≈øhall ≈øee it will bee all forth and cleane.

div.head: A way to take out ≈øpottes in ≈øcarlet or veluet, of what colour or ≈øort ≈øoeuer it bee, not chaunging the colours.
div.p:
Take a hearbe (called of the ≈øurgeons) Saponaria, in frenche called Foullons, in Engli≈øh Sopewort, beat them oft, and take out the iuyce, and put thereof on the ≈øpottes,
then let it ≈øo re≈øt the ≈øpace of one houre if it be in ≈øommer, but if it be in winter let it re≈øt foure houres, then wa≈øhe tho≈øe ≈øpotty places with fayre cleane water, ≈øo ≈øhall it be cleane to ≈øeeme too, but put once agayne the ≈øayde iuyce thereon. Al≈øo if the ≈øcarlet be not dyde in the cleare grain then ye may put therevnto halfe of black ≈øope, with ≈øo much of the ≈øayd iuyce, ≈øo mingle it together, and then frote it thereon, then let it be wa≈øhte in luke warme water, and then ye ≈øhall ≈øee the ≈øpots cleane forth. For this way is proouded by experience to be true.

div.head: Another way to take out yron moles out of linnen.
div.p: Make a chafer ≈øeeth full of water, then take your cloth and wet it with the iuyce of Limons, or ≈øower Oranges, or crabbes, or ≈øower wildinges, and then holde it harde to the ≈øide of the chafer, and euer as it dryeth in, weat it ≈øtill agayne, till ye ≈øee the moll go forth: for all the≈øe thinges afore≈øayd are good, but the iuyce of Limons and Orenges are the be≈øt. So euer as ye haue weate your ≈øpottes with the ≈øayd iuyce, hold it then hard vnto the ≈øyde of the chafer, as is afore≈øayd, thus doe vntill it weare awaye, for this way hath bene proued true often. Or take the boyling iuyce of Sorrell, and lay it therin, and rubbe it with the back of a ≈øpoone till it be out.

div.head: How to take out oylie ≈øpottes out of parchement or writing paper.
div.p: Take a mutton bone and burne it to poulder, then let it be fyne beaten, then put of this poulder on both ≈øides of your ≈øpots, and let it be pre≈øt betweene two hard boordes, the ≈øpace of two dayes, then take it out, and ye ≈øhal ≈øee the oyle to be cleane gone, be it eyther parchment or paper.

div.head: Another way to take out ≈øpottes of paper.
div.p: Ye ≈øhall take off the water willow boughes, and make a≈øhes therof, or a≈øhes of the buds of the vine, with ye hu≈øks of greene beanes, ≈øteepe them in water a day and a night, then put of the ≈øame water on the ≈øpots, then pre≈ø≈øe it; and let it ≈øo remayne for a daye and a nighte, or as ye ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe, and ye ≈øhall ≈øee it will doe well.

div.head: A very good waye to take out ≈øpottes of clothes.
div.p: Take of the rootes of the hearbe called Gentian, in engli≈øh brome, take and burne of it, and make a≈øhes thereof, and with the a≈øhes make a lie, and with the ≈øaid lie, ye ≈øhal wa≈øh your ≈øpotty clothes, and in a ≈øhort ≈øpace it will take away all the ≈øpots therof. Well prooued.

div.head: A good way to take out ≈øpottes out of woollen.
div.p: Take a≈øhe water, and the powder of Allum together, then take of the a≈øhes thereof, and lay it vpon the ≈øpottye places on the cloth, and when it is drie: doe ≈øponge it off, and ye ≈øhall ≈øee it cleane.

div.head: Another agayn≈øt ≈øtaines in linnen cloth.
div.p:
Fir≈øte take your cloth and rubbe it well all ouer with baye ≈øalte, then take an Orange and cutte it in two, and wring the iuyce thereon, and laye the ≈øayde Orange vpon the ≈øpottes al≈øo: and ≈øo lette it re≈øt an hower or two,
then lay them in a bucke and wa≈øh them, and they wil be fayre and cleane. Or el≈øe ye may lay thereon the iuice of ≈øorrell and ≈øalte, and ≈øo put them into the buck as is afore ≈øayd.

div.head: ¬∂ A way to keepe ≈øilke from ≈øtayning in the wa≈øhing.
div.p: Take fayre water and ≈øeeth it, and being all ≈øeething hote, put therevnto of ≈øope and let it ≈øo melt therein, then take it from the fyre, and let it coole til it be almo≈øt colde, and then at your plea≈øure yee may wa≈øhe therewith your clothes, and it will ≈øcoure well, and not ≈øtayne your ≈øilke, and after ye haue wa≈øht them, doe not let them lye weat long together, but lay drye clothes betweene, or el≈øe they he in daunger to ≈øtayne: and this way you may ≈øaue both Sylke and Golde withoute chaunging of theyr colour.

div.head: ¬∂ Another verye good way to keepe Golde from ≈øtayning.
div.p: Fir≈øte take your Golde and annoynte it all ouer with good Honye, then ≈øette it in the Sunne, and lette it re≈øte the ≈øpace of halfe an houre, and nowe and then lette it bee turnde in the Sunne. Then after take and wa≈øhe it in the fore≈øayde ≈øopie water, and this way it ≈øhall neuer chaunge nor ≈øtayne, but keepe colour long.

div.head: ¬∂ Howe to bucke linnen clothes, and to ≈øcoure oute all ≈øpottes of greace.
div.p:
Fir≈øte yee ≈øhall laye all your foule clothes to ≈øoke
in colde water, then driue them as yee doe a bucke of clothes, and when they are well driuen: then ≈øhall yee take them all forth of the bucking tubbe, then laye them agayne abroade in the ≈øayd tubbe, without any lye, and euer as ye lay them betwixt euery cloth: ≈øcrape of chalke thinne all ouer, thus when ye haue all layde them: then put of your lye vnto them, and ≈øo chaunge your lye twi≈øe or thri≈øe after, then take and wa≈øh them forth, and they will be fayre and cleane without greace and very white withall.

div.head: ¬∂ A good way to keepe linnen fayre 20 yeares without remouing, and will not waxe moulye nor rotte.
div.p: Fyr≈øt take your linnen in marche (≈øo much as you intend to keepe vnremoued) and wa≈øhe them, and then drye them fayre agayne. So laye them vp in your chea≈øtes vntill May next following: then ≈øhall ye take them oute and wa≈øh them agayne, when ye haue ≈øo wa≈øhte them, looke that ye doe then drye them thorowly and well, and then folde them fayre vp, and lay them in your che≈øtes or pre≈ø≈øe, and yee ≈øhall not neede for to remooue them in twentye yeares after, yet they ≈øhall continue drye and well.

div.head: How to ≈øponge woollen clothes.
div.p:
Take a quart of fayre water, and let it be heat luke warme on the fyre, then take a quantitie of walkers clay and al to cru≈øh it therin, then let it ≈øtand vntil it be cleare, then poure that water into another potte, and ≈øet it on the fyre agayne, till it begin to ≈øeethe: then take of Venice ≈øope, or other good ≈øope, and put thereof into the ≈øayd water, in ≈øtirring it well all about, then take it of the fyre,
and all hote, ≈øponge or occupye therewith at your plea≈øure, in making it alwayes warme, euer when yee will occupye thereof.

div.head: How to make crane colour Fu≈øtian to be as fayre canuas as at the fir≈øt.
div.p: Fir≈øt for the proofe thereof, take a peece of crane colour Fu≈øtian, and take al≈øo as much of the iuyce of Orenges, or Limons as will weat the ≈øayd peece thorowe, then let it re≈øt and drie in, and the ≈øayd Fu≈øtian wil be as faire canuas as it was before it was coloured, thus if yee can get ≈øo much iuyce of Oranges or Limons for to ≈øerue your purpo≈øe, yee maye returne the colour agayne, what quantitie yee ≈øhall thinke good, for this hath bene well proued.

div.head: Thinges to keepe moughths from clothes, very good in ≈øommer and other times.
div.p:
The flying moughths will bee in the beginning of Iune, and continue till Augu≈øt, but they are chieflye from mid Iuly to mid Augu≈øt. The running moughth he will continue in your chea≈øts all the yeare long, winter and ≈øommer, whiche are greate ≈øpoylers of geare and other thinges. For the flying moughth. Take the powder made of drye Orange Pilles, and the powder of Elecompane rootes mixt together, and ≈øo ca≈øt it among your cloths, al≈øo perfume in a chafingdi≈øh of coles your clothes therewith. Thus you may v≈øe quarterly, and it will ≈øaue theÃÑ. Or ye may take the powder of Arras, with the powder of Ginoper, al≈øo the powder of ≈øitrinum, ca≈øt among clothes ≈øaues them from moughths. Wormewood or Lauendar ≈ømall preuayleth. Some v≈øeth oyle of ≈øpyke to annoynte their chea≈øts, and hang it in bladders therein. Some laies
the hearbe called Flewort, in Latin pulicaris, which if ye lay it in your chaÃÑber, no flea wil breede, ≈øome takes brim≈øtone, & perfumes therewith, but for the running mougth I know nothing but ≈øtrong perfuming, and remoouing your geare.

div.head: A way for to take out ≈øpottes of wollen clothes.
div.p: Take and ≈øeeth of common a≈øhes in fayre water, and the pouder of Allum together, and then take of the ≈øayde a≈øhes and lay thereof on the ≈øpots and ≈øo rubbe it in, then let it drye, and when it is thorowly dryde, then take a ≈øponge and ≈øponge it away, as it is declared of the other afore.

div.head: ¬∂ A good way to helpe all ≈øtaynes in thinne ≈øilkes and woollen clothe.
div.p: Take of good ≈øtrong vineger, and make it luke warme, then dip a black cloth therein, and then rubbe therewith your ≈øtainie ≈øpots al ouer: ≈øo done, theÃÑ take away ≈øo much of the ≈øayd fylth as ye can with a ≈øpoone, as for the re≈øte, ye mu≈øt haue all ready a tailors yron hote, and lay a peece of blacke cloth on the ≈øpottes betwixte the yron and the cloth, and ≈øo drie out all the re≈øt of the ≈øayd filth with the hote yron, and then yee ≈øhall ≈øee it will doe well and bee fayre.

div.head: A plea≈øaunt water to pre≈øerue linnen, or any other thing, yielding a plea≈øaunt ≈øauour a long time after.
div.p:
Take 2 pound of ≈øpike flowers, as much of ro≈øe leaues, one pound of co≈øt mary, with halfe a pound of marioram,
as much of Balnea, two great handfull of Organy or peniryall, foure ounces of mace, a quarter of a pound of Arras poulder, let all the≈øe well ≈øeke together in red wyne, then put it all into a pot clo≈øe ≈øtopte that the ayre doe not pa≈ø≈øe. Let it ≈øtande ≈øo the ≈øpace of foure and twentie houres, then let it bee put into a di≈øtillitorie, and ≈øee that it bee well ≈øtopte, (rounde aboute) with flowre, egges, and water, mixte well together, and ≈øee that no ayre do come nor go oute, but at the ≈øpoute onely. Vpon the ende thereof ye ≈øhall hang a fine linnen cloth with a grayne of mu≈øke or Ambergreace, within it, vppon the which ye ≈øhall alwayes let the ≈øpoute droppe on, and yee ≈øhall ≈øee it will be a pure water for that purpo≈øe, ye ≈øhall al≈øo take to the di≈øtilling of the fore≈øayd thinges, halfe a pounde of baye leaues, ≈øo ≈øhall this water be good for the purpo≈øe as is afore mentioned.

div.head: A good way to wa≈øhe a ≈øhirte, and ≈øaue the Golde or Silke thereon, from ≈øtaining.
div.p:
Take a newe ≈øhirte fyr≈øte of all afore it be euer weat, and lay the coller and ruffes or ≈øilke in pi≈ø≈øe ≈øomewhat warme halfe an houre ≈øpace, then take it forth, and then wa≈øh him in hote ≈øchalding licar, or ≈øeeth him, and it ≈øhall neuer ≈øtayne the ≈øilke. If ye haue not pi≈ø≈øe, yee maye take groundes of ≈øtrong beare or ale, and let the ≈øilke lye therin, the night before ye doe wa≈øh it. And this hath bene oft proued very true. But alwayes ye mu≈øt fore≈øee, that ye hang not your clothes in the hote ≈øunne, after they bee wa≈øhte, but laye another cloth thereon betwixte the Sunne and it, or el≈øe the Sunne wyll chaunge both Golde, Siluer and Silke. Therefore it is better
to hang them in ≈øome place of ≈øhade after their wa≈øhing, if ye can. Al≈øo to ≈øope your water to much, or your clothes is an occa≈øion to ≈øtaine both golde and ≈øilkes. A very good way is: fir≈øt to melt your ≈øope in the lycour, and then let it coole, and ≈øo to wa≈øh your clothes therein.

div.head: Agayn≈øt clothes ≈øtaynde with wine or vineger.
div.p: Take of warme Cow milke and wa≈øh your cloth therin, or wa≈øh it in whay and ≈øalt, other el≈øe as ≈øoone as your clothes are ≈øo ≈øtaynde by mi≈øchaunce of wine or other thinges, doe ca≈øt of ≈øalte thereon incontinent, ≈øo then it will pre≈øerue it from ≈øtayning, whether it bee wollen or linnen.

div.head: A very good way to take forth waxe or ro≈øin dropte on ≈øilke, wollen or linnen.
div.p:
Whereas ye ≈øhal haue any ≈øuch occa≈øion to take forth waxe or Ro≈øine dropt on any ≈øilkes, or other clothes. Fir≈øt ye ≈øhall make a pre≈ø≈øing yron hote, or ≈øome ≈øyluer ≈øpoone, with a cole of fyre therein, take eyther of them when they he hote, and fir≈øt whereas any Ro≈øin or waxe is dropt, yee ≈øhall fir≈øt rubbe on the ≈øayd droppes of waxe or ro≈øin al ouer: with the end of a tallow candle, theÃÑ take eyther your yron or ≈øpoone afore≈øayd, and holde it thereon, laying a peece of broune paper betwixte your yron and your wax, then after yee haue a little ≈øo touched it with the heate, (the waxe and tallow will mingle together, and ≈øoke into the broune paper) then take it off, and annoynt it with the ≈øayd tallow agayne, and then holde your hote yron, or ≈øpoone, as before, and thus ye mu≈øt doe, as aften as ye ≈øhal ≈øee cau≈øe, vntill it be all cleane forth. If the waxe be dropt thorow on both ≈øides, v≈øe the one ≈øide like the other, and ≈øo
ye ≈øhall get it cleane: and looke euer that ye ≈øhifte youre browne paper to a cleaner place, from the place it was before touched with waxe, and this order keeping, it ≈øhall be al wel and cleane. Often proued.

div.head: A ≈øope to take out all ≈øpottes in woollen cloth.
div.p: Take of Venice ≈øope a quarter of a pound, the yolkes of three egges, of ≈øalt finely beaten halfe a ≈øpoonefull, of the iuyce of Betes, halfe a ≈øpoonefull, or as much as will make it thicke like a pa≈øte, then make them into pretye balles, and let them drye out of the heate of the ≈øunne, in ≈øome ≈øhadow place, and when≈øoeuer ye will occupy thereof, fir≈øt wet your ≈øpots thorowe with fayre cleare water, and then take your ball and rubbe it thereon, and wa≈øh it then cleane forth as is afore mentioned of the other, thus doe, and yee ≈øhall ≈øee that they ≈øhall be cleane forth, as before.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Fyr≈øte ye ≈øhall take of white ≈øope halfe a pounde, and ≈øhread it very ≈ømall, then take of the gall of an Oxe, or of a hee Goate, with ≈øome Allum, of eyther of them an ouÃÑce, take the yolkes of two egges, with a quantitie of fine ≈øifted a≈øhes, put them altogether in a morter, and beat them, and when they be well mixt, make them into balles, and when≈øoeuer ye ≈øhall neede thereof, take of fayre warme water, and rubbe the place all ouer therewith, and then ≈øtrike with your ball thereon, and then ≈øhall ye rubbe cloth vpon cloth, and wa≈øhe it then foorth, as afore≈øayde, and it will be cleane.

div.head: Another way good to helpe ≈øpottes or ≈øtaynes.
div.p: Ye ≈øhall fir≈øt take halfe a gall of an Oxe, the older the better, of feny greke made in fyne poulder halfe a pounde, a quarter of a pounde of white ≈øope, a gallon of ≈øtrong common lye, mixe altogether therein, and ≈øet them on the fyre, and ≈øeeth them ≈øoftly till they be halfe wa≈øted, and when≈øoeuer ye will occupye thereof, heate it warme, and wa≈øh your ≈øpottes therwith, in mixing it often with faire colde water, and it ≈øhall doe well.

div.head: How to take out ≈øpots of white ≈øilkes, or other coloures.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt Aquavite, three pintes, with the which you ≈øhall wete your ≈øpottes, & take a new layde egge and beate it, and rub thereon your ≈øaid ≈øpots, and ≈øo ≈øet in the ≈øonne and let it drye in: this done, wa≈øhe it then with a fre≈øh and cleare water, and then wring or pre≈ø≈øe the ≈øayd water forth, or pre≈ø≈øe it betwixt your haÃÑds, and ≈øo they ≈øhall be cleane, as for cloth in grayne, ye maye wa≈øh the ≈øpots well with Allum water, then rubbe cloth vnto cloth, and ≈øo wa≈øh it forth with cleare water agayn, and it will be well. If it be not at the fir≈øt all cleane oute: doe ≈øo likewi≈øe agayne, ≈øo long as ye ≈øhal ≈øee cau≈øe of any ≈øpots remayne, and ≈øo they ≈øhal be well.

div.head: A proued way how to take out oylie ≈øpottes out of cloth.
div.p:
Take of the oyle of Tartar, ≈øo much as wil couer your other ≈øtaynes, and put it thereon, and ≈øtraighte way take it off agayne, and wa≈øhe it then well with fayre warme
water. Then take cold water al≈øo and wa≈øh it iii or foure times ouer, after that, in chaunging it ≈øtill with new water, this done, you ≈øhal ≈øee it will be as fayre as the re≈øt, and as it was before.

div.head: Another way to take out all waxe, Ro≈øin or pitche, on Silkes or other clothes.
div.p: Fir≈øt take of tallow or other greace (be it ≈øalt or fre≈øh) and melte it, and being ≈øeething hote, put thereof on your ≈øayd ≈øpottes of waxe, Ro≈øine, or Pitche, then take of hote licor, and hold your ≈øayd ≈øpottes therein, & then rub cloth vpon cloth, betwixt your haÃÑds. So done, then wring forth the ≈øayd greazie water, and if ye then ≈øee it will not be al cleane forth, ≈øerue it ≈øo agayne, annoynting your ≈øayde ≈øpottes with tallowe or greace, and then doe clean≈øe foorth the grea≈øye water as afore is mentioned. For this waye hath bene well and often proued, and doeth helpe.

div.head: ¬∂ To take foorth gteace out of Silke, Veluet, Moccado or others.
div.p: Take and heate water and put a handful of cleane feathers therin, & then let it coole til ye may ≈øuffer your haÃÑd therin, & lay your ≈øilke abroad, and take your feathers and rub al ouer the ≈øpot, then rub therouer with Ca≈øtile ≈øope, and then with your feathers again al vp & down, weting them twi≈øe or thri≈øe, and ≈øo rub it vp & down, theÃÑ wring it a little & dry it in the ≈øunne or wind: but if it be Veluet, after ye haue ≈øo rubde it: the veluet wil lye, then mu≈øt ye take a cloth of woollen, & heat it, theÃÑ annoynt it light ouer with butter, & chafe your cloth together, to rub in ye butter, theÃÑ heat it a little, & rub your veluet vp & down therwith, & it wil then ri≈øe again, and be as fayre as before.

div.head: To take out ≈øpottes of cloth.
div.p: They take the ≈øtraight bones in ≈øheepes feete that are ≈øodde, and drye them and make them into poulder, with the which you ≈øhall lay on the ≈øpotted cloth, layde in the Sunne, and rubbe this poulder thereon till it goe all foorth.

div.head: To dye wooll red.
div.p: Ye ≈øhall put too foure pounde of woollen yearne, tenne ounces of Allum, and ≈øeeth it with branne water ≈øo much as ye ≈øhall thinke good, then take your yearne oute, and put that water out of that Kettle, and put therein agayne three partes of fre≈øh branne water, and one parte of fayre cleare water, then warme it a little on the fyre, then put therein two pound of grening weede, and let it ≈øo warme a while, then put therein your wooll, and ≈øtyr it wel with a ≈øticke the ≈øpace of three howers, but let it not ≈øeeth in any wi≈øe, ≈øo done, then take out your wooll agayne, and put it agayne into your Kettle, and put thereto half a gla≈ø≈øefull of vn≈øleakte lime, with as much of common a≈øhes, and thereto put your wooll agayne, and ≈øtyrre it with a ≈øtaffe ≈øixe or ≈øeuen Paterno≈øter whiles, than take foorth youre wooll, and ye ≈øhall haue a fayre colour. But if yee will haue it yet a more ≈øanguine coloure, then mu≈øt you putte into your Kettle halfe a little gla≈ø≈øe full of more lime, and a little gla≈ø≈øe full of common a≈øhes, and thereto put your wooll agayne, and ≈øtirre it well ≈øtill foure or fyue Paterno≈øter whyles, then take foorth your wooll and wa≈øh it, and ≈øo ye ≈øhall haue a very fayre colour.

div.head: Another way to make wooll a fayre red.
div.p: When as your wooll is made red after the fir≈øt maner then ≈øhall ye ca≈øt away that licour that is in the Kettle, and put into it fayre water, and put thereto the cru≈øe full of fayre made lye of common a≈øhes, and therein put al≈øo an ounce of Allum, then as ≈øoone as it beginneth to ≈øeeth, put therein your wooll, and ≈øtyrre it well therein foure or fiue paterno≈øter whiles, then take it foorth and wa≈øhe it, and ≈øo ye ≈øhall haue your wooll a fayre colour. This maner of dying is after the order of Dorneke in Flaunders.

div.head: To dye a fayre yealowe.
div.p: If ye will dye yealow with wood, take off the wood leaues, and cut off the rootes, then cut them in peeces, and lay them to ≈øoke in lye of commoÃÑ a≈øhes three houres, then ≈øeeth it a quarter of an hower, till ye thinke it be meetely well ≈øodde. Then put therein two quartes of water, and as much ≈øtale Vrine of ≈øixe dayes olde at the lea≈øt, ≈øo let them ≈øeeth together a little, then clean≈øe it thorow a ≈øiue, and then put vnto the ≈øame agayne, of lye and Vrine as afore≈øayd. Then ≈øtrayne it thorow a fayre cloth and ≈øeeth it, and to two pounde of wood take two pounde of Verdegreace, with the lye that ye haue ≈øod, your woad and all putting them in your ≈øayd colour, which mu≈øt be medled and well ≈øtirred all together. Then ≈øhall ye boyle it all a little, and it ≈øhall be well.

div.head: Another colour to dye a yealow with wood.
div.p:
Take and ≈øet a pot with water on the fire, and make it warme, then take a≈øhes made of Oken woade, and ca≈øt thereof into the pot with water, and being warme take it from the fyre, and fiyre it well. Then couer it clo≈øe til the
next daye. Then poore the cleare≈øt lye thereof thorowe a cloth ≈øoftly into another ve≈ø≈øel or pan, then take of good wood, and breake the rootes off, and then cut them ≈ømall, then wa≈øh & rince them in cold water, & then put theÃÑ into the lie, and there let them ≈øoke a night, then take & ≈øeethe it, til the halfe be con≈øumed, and when it is well ≈øod, then all hote, clen≈øe it thorow a fayre cloth, then mu≈øt yee haue of verdegreace wel & finely beaten into pouder, and blend therof with a ≈øpoone among≈øt your other ≈øtuffe, this mu≈øt be done incontinent therevpon, and al≈øo your lye thervnto mu≈øt be very ≈øtrong made.

div.head: How to dye linnen or thread red.
div.p:
As when ye wil dye anye Linnen or threade red, yee ≈øhal take one pound of ≈øamfleure, and let it ≈øoke halfe a day and a nighte in water milke warme, then put it into a thicke bagge or ≈øacke, and therein wa≈øhe and rynce it in the riuer till the bagge bee therewith red, then wring the water well foorth, and ≈øo take oute your Samfloure, and ≈øpread it vppon a fayre boorde or Table and make (as it were) a little thinne bedde thereof, then ≈øtrewe thereon of white a≈øhes, in making beddes of youre Samfleure, and when ye haue ≈øtrewde them with a≈øhes, ye ≈øhal take to one pounde of Samfleure, a guarter of a pouÃÑd of a≈øhes, which a≈øhes mu≈øt be burnt and made of the lyes of white Wine, and it mu≈øt be well chafte betwixte your handes, the one again≈øt the other, then make thereof a ≈ømall heape, and ≈øo let it re≈øt the ≈øpace of fyue houres. Then ≈øhall ye rubbe it agayne till it waxe warme, then haue readye a fayre ba≈øen, and ≈øette it vnder your ≈øtuffe, that it may runne therein, and al≈øo wring out the iuyce thereof into the ≈øayd Ba≈øon. Then ca≈øt therein a pynte of wine vyneger that is very good, then yee maye putte therein a pounde of yearne, and it ≈øhall doe well. But
to dye your Linnen cloth, ye ≈øhall put it in before youre yearne or Fu≈øtian. Then lay it therein a day and a night, then take forth your linnen or yearne, and then put therein a gallon of a≈øhes of the A≈øhe tree, and therevnto youre linnen, yearne, or fu≈øtian, and ≈øo let it lye therein halfe an houre, then take it oute and wring it as well as you can, then by and by hang it in the ≈øunne, then take that water that ye ≈øoked fir≈øt your Samfleure in, and ≈øtrayne it (as afore≈øayde) into the ba≈øon vnto the other colour, then put therein a gla≈ø≈øefull of Vineger, and then you maye putte therein your yearne, fu≈øtion, or linnen cloth, and doe therevnto as is afore≈øayd.

div.head: Another way to dye Linnen in a fayre ro≈øe redde colour.
div.p:
To dye a fayre redde ro≈øe colour of Linnen, yee ≈øhall take to euery iiii. yardes and a halfe of Linnen, halfe a li. of good gall nots, and ≈øeeth them in fayre water al whole, the ≈øpace of ii houres, then take it from the fyre, & poure that water into another ve≈ø≈øell or fatte, then put your linnen into the ≈øayd water, and let it ≈øoke therein the ≈øpace of foure houres, then take it forth and wring the lycoure wel forth. Then take fayre water in a kettle, and ≈øet it on the fyre, and put therein a quarter of a pounde of Allum, and when it is readye to ≈øeeth, take it from the fyre, and put youre cloth therein as ≈øoone as yee haue wrong and ≈øtraynde oute your gals afore≈øayde, but lette it drye a night before fir≈øte, and then turne it well therein the ≈øpace of a quarter of an houre. So take it forth and wring it well, & then ≈øeeth two ounces of Bra≈øill in fayre water, the ≈øpace of two houres, then take that froÃÑ the fire, and hang another kettle ouer the fire, and putte therein gruys water, ≈øo warme it a little, and ca≈øt therein two li. of grening wede, then put your linnen cloth therein, and
looke that no Allum haue bene in that water. Then let it lye therin halfe an houre, and ≈øtyrre it wel with a ≈øtaffe and then take out thereof the ≈øayd linnen, ye may then ca≈øt away the ≈øame liquor, and wa≈øh your kettle cleane, and put therein of the cleare≈øt bra≈øill water and let it wel colour therein. Then take your Linnen and wa≈øh it wel in fayre water, then take of fayre water in a panne, with a little Allum and ≈øo ≈øeeth them both together: and therin ≈øeeth your Linnen cloth fiue or ≈øixe paterno≈øter whiles. Then take out the ≈øayd cloth and wring it wel, and after that put the ≈øayd cloth into the kettle of bra≈øill water, and therein ye ≈øhal turne and wind it wel, the ≈øpace of a quarter of an houre, then take it forth and wring it a little, and likewi≈øe you ≈øhall doe with the dying of the Fu≈øtian, but vnto your Fu≈øtian you mu≈øt haue two partes more of Verdigreace and Allum, and that your Fu≈øtian mu≈øt lye therein half a day and a night, then wring it forth, and let it drye, then after yee maye ray≈øe his cotton with cardes meete for that purpo≈øe, if yee wil haue your Linnen more fayrer, ca≈øt in the Kettle with your ≈øayd bra≈øill, ≈øome lye made of white Lime, then put your cloth therein, then turne and wind it therein the ≈øpace of foure pater no≈øters, and then take it forth thereof and wring it well, and ≈øo hang it vp to drye.

div.head: How to make your branne water, wherewithall you ≈øhall v≈øe to dye red.
div.p:
Ye ≈øhal take a hat full of wheate branne, and take ≈øo much water as wil go into the ≈ømal kettles, ≈øo let it haue a welling or two on the fire. Then poure it into a fatte. then take two other kettle fuls of water and warme it, and put it therein al≈øo, but fir≈øt ≈øtirre it wel, and ≈øo couer it wel. The fir≈øte day you mu≈øt ≈øtyre it often, and then it will be the better, then ≈øhall ye let it ≈øtande foure or fyue
dayes till it waxe the riper, and which will be the better for your purpo≈øe, and then ye may occupye as you ≈øhal ≈øee cau≈øe.

div.head: For an yron moll in Linnen.
div.p: To take forth any yron moll in linnen cloth, take a chafing di≈øh with coles, then couer the coles with a pewter di≈øhe ≈øo let it be hote. Then lay your linnen thereon where the moll is, and with a Limon, or an Oringe, but the Limon is better, to rubbe your moll therewith, and ≈øtill as it dryeth in, lay the iuyce thereon, and ≈øtil rubbe it ≈øo, till it be all cleane, and this way will haue it all out. Oft prooued.

div.head: To dye ≈øilke quoyues in a redde.
div.p: Ye ≈øhall fir≈øt lay your ≈øilke in Allum water, and let it ≈øeeth therein, and with branne water al≈øo halfe an houre long both together, then take a little grening weede, and the like of branne water, and let it be made hote, and put the ≈øilke therein, but let it not ≈øeeth, but take it oute and rince it in lye, and then in water, and then it wil be fayre and well.

div.head: To dye ≈øilke in a ≈øanguine colour.
div.p: Ye ≈øhall dye ≈øilke in a ≈øanguine, as ye mu≈øt in al ≈øortes take Allum as ye doe grening weede, then mu≈øt yee take a little fayre water, with a little bra≈øill, and ≈øeeth them together. Then take part thereof, and ≈øeeth the ≈øilke therin, and as that is takeÃÑ out, ≈øo take an other, and then the thyrd tyme, then put it in lye, and ≈øo clen≈øe it, as is afore≈øayde.

div.head: To dye Silke blue.
div.p: If ye will dye blue ≈øilke, that ≈øilke mu≈øt then be white, which ye mu≈øt fir≈øt ≈øoke in water, and then wring it forth then ye ≈øhall put it in your blue dye, and there ye maye make it with a light colour or darke as ye plea≈øe.

div.head: A fayre greene to dye.
div.p: If ye will haue a fayre greene, take a little branne water, and a little allum, and ≈øeeth them together, and when the Allum is molton, put your ≈øilke therein, and lette it ≈øeeth the fourth part of an houre. Then take again a little branne water, and a little wood, and put it therein al≈øo, till that it waxe a fayre darke yealow. If ye will haue it more yealower, then put it in the blue dye, wherein yee may make it light or darke as ye plea≈øe.

div.head: To dye black ≈øilke.
div.p: Take to one pound of ≈øilk, xii. gall nots, and beat them to pouder, then ≈øeeth the ≈øilke with the gals in fayre water, a good halfe houre long, then take of the blacke dye, and therein ≈øeeth it another half houre, then take it forth and let it be colde, and then put it agayne into the blacke dye, and let it there ≈øeeth another halfe houre, if then it be not fayre: let it ≈øeeth therein ≈øo long till it waxe a fayre black, then ≈øponge it in the water, and ≈øo let it drye.

div.head: A purple ≈øilke to dye.
div.p:
When ye wil die a purple ≈øilke, ye ≈øhal take to one pouÃÑd of ≈øilke, 4 ounces of Allum, and ≈øeeth the Allum in common water, & lay the ≈øilke therein, and let it ≈øo lye foure
houres. Then take to euery pound of ≈øilke, two pound of purple colour, & ≈øeeth it together as hereafter is written, which is, ye ≈øhal take halfe pi≈ø≈øe, and half water togither, & ≈øeeth it therein till it waxe cleare & fayre, and theÃÑ ≈øpoÃÑge it in fayre water. Al≈øo to eche pound of ≈øilke it behooueth to haue foure ounces of Allum. Al≈øo for red ≈øilke to dye with crap dye, ≈øo calde in dutche, which ye ≈øhall dye with foure pound of Allum, and al≈øo ye ≈øhall dye ≈øanguine ≈øilk with allum, and al≈øo yelow ye ≈øhall dye with allum.

div.head: To make a good black dye.
div.p: Take a pounde of galles, and fourth parte of coperas, and ≈øeeth the≈øe together, then put the cloth therein, and ≈øtyrre it wel about, then hang it to drie, then prepare your dye as thus, take a good great fat, and put therin a fourth part of Rye meale, and halfe ≈øo muche of ≈øwarfe (of the grind≈øtone, and ≈øo much of elder barke, and in like of olde yron, and the ≈øcales of yron, as it comes of by the hammer beating, ≈øtyrre this all well togither, and ≈øo let it ≈øtande three dayes or euer ye put your cloth therein, and at eche tyme let your linnen drye afore ye put it therein.

div.head: To dye a greene.
div.p: Take a light blue colour and put it into Allum water two houres long, then hang it to the time, there as the wynde may drye it, and then put it into the fore≈øayd wood and ≈øo v≈øe it as it is afore declared.

div.head: To dye a carna≈øion.
div.p:
Take purper that is drye, and ≈øay it to ≈øoke a night in pi≈ø≈øe, then take your cloth that is allomde, and drye & put
it therein, but yee ≈øhall ≈øeeth the purper twi≈øe in fayre water, then ≈øet another fatte by the fyre, and let it ≈øeeth, and therein yee ≈øhall fir≈øte put your cloth, and then all weate, put it in to your dye, till it be fayre ynough.

div.head: To make a redde carnation.
div.p: To make a redd carnation dye, ye mu≈øt dye your white cloth, linnen or woollen, or ≈øilke yearne, to doe it well, yee ≈øhall gall and Allome it well. Ye mu≈øt take an hearbe called Foli in dutche, that ≈øhall ye finde by ditches & banks, take a pound thereof that is drie, this is in tuftes, and it is hote like wee a≈øhes, and carnation in ≈øight, therewith men doe make a red carnation woollen cloth, with the greene or white, or of ≈øilke, and if any carnation haue lo≈øt his colour, or if anye carnation haue lo≈øt his dye, with that ye ≈øhall dye it agayne, that it ≈øhall not lee≈øe his colour, and to foure elles of cloath, ye ≈øhall take a pound gruis, or of that hearbe afore named, whiche ye ≈øhall beate to pouder, Then ≈øhall yee take lye made of Oke a≈øhes, mixe a parte therewith, and another part of cleare pi≈ø≈øe cleare and old, of eche like muche. If ye will haue a light dye, take pi≈ø≈øe newe made, and of the fore≈øayde lye, in like much & therewith ye ≈øhall dye, with the fore≈øaid poulder put therein, & as it is ≈øod, put in that which ye woulde dye, and ≈øeethe it two houres long, and then let it drye.

div.head: To dye Linnen.
div.p:
Ye ≈øhall fir≈øte take to one ≈øtone of flockes fyue pound of ≈øope a≈øhes (which are calde in Dutche Wee A≈ø≈øeen) of the be≈øt, with ≈øixteene gallons of water, ≈øeeth it together an houre long, and then let it cleare one nighte, then gentlye poure of the vppermo≈øt thereof, and ≈øeeth your flockes therein one houre long, and then prooue if your flockes
or ≈øilke be ynough ≈øod, al≈øo take a little of your Flockes in your hande, and thru≈øt it hard to a redde cloth, al≈øo put it in your mouth, and if it go by and by aparte like a rype apple, then it is ynough ≈øod. TheÃÑ ≈øpoÃÑge it in fayre water, and then putte it in branne water, according to the quantitie of the woollen cloth, and ≈øeeth your Flocks therein, then take it out thereof, and take bra≈øill and put it in water according to the quantitye of the linnen, that is to ech elle of cloth foure ounces of Bra≈øill, and as the bra≈øil hath ≈øod a while, then ≈øtrayne the bra≈øil thorow a cloth, and put it agayne into your Kettle, and your Flocks al≈øo, and let them ≈øeeth, then take a Ladle full of lye and put it therin, thus ≈øhall ye make it as hye as you will, and if yee will haue it more higher, then put more lye therein, al≈øo for three pounde of Flockes, take foure ounces of Allum, and ≈øeeth them together, and if yee will ≈øeeth dyde Flockes, take lye of Sope a≈øhes, as before it is written, which yee ≈øhall ≈øeeth with Sope a≈øhes, then ≈øcoure it, and lette it drye.

div.head: To dye cloth with facet Wood.
div.p:
As ye will dye cloth with faucet Wood, ye mu≈øt make your lye with ≈øope a≈øhes of Denmarke, and rayne water, which ye ≈øhall let ≈øtand three houres long, then ≈øeeth it, but the Woad mu≈øt be fir≈øt ≈øod in the lye, and when it is ≈øodde, let it bee cooled with other colder and ≈øharper lye, with the la≈øt lye ye ≈øhall put too one pounde of yearne, a great peece of Allum, and put it therein. Then ≈øhal ye put that dye into a fayre Kettle or fatte, then take two ounces of ≈øpani≈øhe greene, which ye ≈øhal ≈øoke therein two or three houres long, then to≈ø≈øe and pu≈øh it vp and downe twi≈øe or thri≈øe, and wring it, and with colder lye put therein, and te≈ø≈øe it with a di≈øhe too and froe. Al≈øo another manner
is, take a di≈øhe full of vnflect lyme, and quenche it with water, then take too di≈øhe full of wood a≈øhes, and mixe it with the chalke all together well, and there of yee ≈øhall make a good ≈øtrong lye, and let it three or foure times run thorow the tubbe, then take the faucet woad, and hew or cut it in ≈ømall peeces, & ca≈øt it into the lye, and let it ≈øeeth therein halfe an houre long. Then put therein ≈øope a≈øhes, and let it ≈øeeth another good halfe hower, take it then off, & put thereto ≈øpani≈øh greene, & let it boile twi≈øe, or thri≈øe, and then ≈øponge it, al≈øo with three pound of faucet woad, it behoueth to haue two ounces of ≈øpani≈øh green, & as the cloth haue bene in the fir≈øt licor, if then it be too broune or too yealow, then put thereto of wyne a≈øhes, & a little alluÃÑ.

div.head: To dye woollen cloth ≈øanguine.
div.p:
To dye woollen cloth fayre, ye ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øeethe good rye meale in fayre water, and then put it in a fayre tubbe or pan. Then ca≈øt fayre water thereon, and let it ≈øo ≈øtande three dayes to cleare, then take of that water, & put therein two ounces of allum, to an elle of cloth, and let it ≈øeethe two houres long, then let it hang & coole without wringing. Then put that water forth of the ve≈ø≈øell with the meale, and put therein a pound of the be≈øt grening wede, and heate that al≈øo, but let it not ≈øeeth, theÃÑ put your cloth therein, & to≈ø≈øe it wel with your hands without ≈øeething, and take it forth and put it in a panne with fayre lye, and let it lye therein, and ≈øo let it drye, and it will be a red. If yee will make fayrer, you mu≈øt haue of bra≈øill, take an ounce of Allum and allum it as afore≈øaide in another water, then ≈øeeth two ounces of allum with that bra≈øill, in branne water made, and as the bra≈øill haue ≈øod a while therein, ≈øo put therein of cold water, then take ≈øo muche thereof out as will weat your cloth in, and ≈øtyrre it well therein, then ≈øhall ye take of other dye, vntil the time that
it hath ≈øufficient ynough, if yee will haue the ≈øame a ≈øanguine, lay it in fayre lye of Sope a≈øhes, and there it will haue a fayre ≈øanguine dye.

div.head: To dye woollen yearne, or cloth.
div.p: To make this dye, put too foure pounde of woollen yarne, or cloth, two pounde of woad. Put this woad in a Kettle, and ca≈øt therein of fayre water, then ca≈øt agayne halfe a tin di≈øhe full of a≈øhes out of the fyre, and as ≈øoone as it ≈øeethes, put your woollen yarne therein, then let it ≈øeeth eyght or nyne pater no≈øter whiles long, then putte your yarne forth, and put a little water in, out of the kettle, and then a few a≈øhes out of the harth, and put your woollen yarne agayne therein: and ≈øo let it ≈øeeth a good while, if it be a broune blue, it ≈øhall be a darke greene, and if it be white woollen yearne, ≈øo it ≈øhal be a yealow colour

div.head: Agayne to dye woollen yearne.
div.p:
As ye will dye woollen yarne that is greene, youre yearne ye ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øeeth in branne water, whiche is to vnder≈øtand, to foure pound of yarne, ten ounces of Allum, and let it ≈øeeth two houres, then wring that out, and put it in the dye thus made. To foure pound of wooll yearne take two pound of woad, and ≈øeeth the woad well with hearth a≈øhes, in lye made a day before, ≈øo let it ≈øeethe the fourth part of an houre, then put the cleare into a cleane fatte or ve≈ø≈øell, then take the fourth parte of an ounce of ≈øpani≈øh greene, calde Verdigreace, poulder it well & ca≈øt it therein, and ≈øtirre it with a ≈øtick or ≈øtaffe, then put in your yearne, ≈øo turne and to≈ø≈øe it therein the fourthe parte of an hower, and then let it drye. If it bee not fayre ynough, then put it in agayne, and doe as before,
al≈øo as ye would dye blue woollen yearne, yet ≈øhall put it fir≈øt in warme water, then wring it forth and dye it blue, as it is afore≈øayd.

div.head: To dye with bra≈øill as red as a ro≈øe.
div.p: Take ≈øixe elles of linnen, and thereto halfe a pounde of beaten galles, of the be≈øt: then put it in fayre water, and let it ≈øeeth about two houres, but the galles ≈øhoulde rather be all whole, and when they are ≈øodde, ≈øet it from the fyre, and put it gently in another Kettle or fatte, and then put your linnen therein, as hote as you maye handle it, and ≈øtyrre it therein foure houres long, that done, then wring it well forth, and hang it to drye. Then take foure ounces of Allum, and ≈øeeth it with water, and when it is ≈øod, take it from the fyre, and put your galled cloth therein, as hote as ye may ≈øuffer it, the ≈øpace of a quarter of an houre, then take your branne water and put thereof in a Kettle, and as it is warme, put therein two pound of grening weede, let it the fir≈øt time ≈øoke well therein, and let it be well and hote, but not ≈øeeth, and then put your cloth therein, and ≈øtirre and handle it well at the fir≈øt with your handes, nye halfe an houre with a ≈øtaffe to≈øt well al about, and wel handled in the dye, and then ye ≈øhall take youre cloth and ≈øponge it in water and wa≈øhe it cleane. Then take a little allum, and ≈øeeth it with water, then ≈øhall yee haue two ounces of bra≈øill ≈øodde in light water, and putte your cloth therein fiue paterno≈øters long. Then ≈øhall yee haue two ounces of bra≈øill ≈øodde in light water, and putte your cloth therein, then handle and ≈øtyrre it well therein and ≈øtirre it well about the ≈øpace of a quarter of an houre and wring it not to ≈øore, then drie it. Then if it be not dry ynough, then weate it as before ≈øayde.

div.head: Howe to make a greene water.
div.p: Take ny halfe an ounce of Verdigreace, and cru≈øhe it well in a woodden di≈øhe, then put thereto the yolke of an egge and too blades of ≈øaffron, then take of the leaues of ≈øpurge, halfe a handfull, and beate them in a morter, and thereto ca≈øt a good gla≈ø≈øefull of Vineger, and ≈øtrayne it thorow a cloth. Then take of this ≈øtuffe, and put thereof in a di≈øhe with the Verdigreace, and ≈øtirre it well togeather and make it thinne, that it may be the better to dye, or to worke with a pen≈øill, or as ye ≈øhall ≈øeeme be≈øt.

div.head: To dye fayre Linnen with bra≈øill.
div.p:
Ye ≈øhall take fayre water, and heate it ouer the fyre, then ≈øhall ye haue the poulder of galles, and put thereof into the Kettle ouer the fyre, and ≈øo let it ≈øeeth a quarter of an hower: then take it from the fyre, and take another ve≈ø≈øell and put therein ≈øo much colde water, as of the other in the Kettle, and put that hote in the Kettle therevnto. Then put your cloth therein, and ≈øtirre it well vp and downe therein, and as ye haue done ≈øo a while, then let it lye therein foure houres long in that gall water, then take your Kettle agayne with other fayre water, and ≈øet it ouer the fyre and make it hote, then put of AlluÃÑ therein to the kettle ouer the fyre, and as that water is hote, and the Allum melted, yee mu≈øt then haue another ve≈ø≈øell or fatte with colde water, as muche as of the other hote water, and put the Allum water therein, then putte your cloth therein, and ≈øtyrre it as afore≈øayde, and ≈øo let it then lye therein foure houres long, ≈øo done then yee ≈øhall wring it out and hang it to drye, or to drye in the ayre, but let it not bee too drye. Then ≈øhall ye take youre bra≈øill made in poulder, and put it in the panne, and ≈øo let
it ≈øeeth therein, the quarter of an houre, and before that bra≈øill do ≈øeeth, ye ≈øhal take wheat flower, & put therein, & mixe it altogether well in a di≈øh, and put it into the Kettle before it do ≈øeeth: thus done, let it ≈øeeth, and as it hath ≈øod, then take forth ≈øo much of the bra≈øil, as ye may put in your cloth, and ≈øtirre it well about, as is afore declared, thus done, let your cloth re≈øt therein a good while, then wring it forth, & hang it to dry, & as it is dry, ye ≈øhall take that lycor that it hath layn in, and put that away, theÃÑ take agayn ≈øo much bra≈øill as before, & put that cloth therin agayne, and then hang it to dry, and as it is dry, then put it in another lycor, & hang it agayn to dry, & then it is ful done. And to know the quantitie of weight, which is, to euery elle of linnen cloth, ye ≈øhal take a loot of gall pouder ≈øo calde in dutch, and as much of allum, and to eche elle of cloth one ounce of bra≈øill.

div.head: To make a fayre yealow.
div.p: To make a yelow, that ye may worke with oyle, or water ye ≈øhal take woad, ≈øo much as ye ≈øhall plea≈øe, & let it ≈øtand to ≈øoke a night and a day in lye made with ≈øope a≈øhes, and when it is thus ≈øoked, then ≈øhal ye ≈øeeth it, & couer it clo≈øe ≈øo long as it ≈øeeth, thus done, then ≈øet it from the fire, & put that lycor into another pan, & ≈øo ≈øtrayne it thorow a clea ‚Ä¢ cloth, then take the pan & poure the thinne≈øt aboue off, ≈øo long til ye ≈øee the dye vndercome with al, then take ye fore ≈øayd cloth, and ≈øtraine it again thorow it, into another pan ≈øo long as ye think the ≈øub≈øtaunce of the woad doe tary in the cloth, til ye thinke that that water is thin ynough to ≈øtrayne, and then ye may v≈øe it.

div.head: A fayre Linnen cloth to dye blue.
div.p:
For to dye a fayre blue, ye ≈øhal take a pan of fayre water,
& hang it ouer the fire, & let it be ≈øeething hote, then mu≈øt ye haue a ve≈ø≈øell of halfe an Ame, ≈øo cald in dutch, or thereabout, & as your lycor is hote, put thereto 3 pouÃÑd of wheat bran, & 3 pouÃÑd of a≈øhes, & a pound of grening wede, ≈øtir al this in the pan, & let it ≈øeeth iii. or iiii. paterno≈øters loÃÑg, theÃÑ take of floray vnder half a pound, & ≈øoke it in faire water, & let it there re≈øt a quarter of an houre couered, theÃÑ take your clean ve≈ø≈øel or Ame, & therin put your ≈øoked floray, then take the hote lycor ouer the fire, but let it coole or ye put it into the fatte, then put it in and ≈øtirre it well, and ≈øo couer it wel and clo≈øe, and let it ≈øo re≈øt ≈øixe houres long, then vncouer it and ≈øtirre it wel about a good while then couer it clo≈øe again, and let re≈øt other vi houres, then vncouer it & ≈øtir it as before, & ≈øo ≈øtop it agayn, then vncouer it within two or three houres, & looke if the die begin to come, or begin to wax green, if they doe not, let it re≈øt longer and ≈øtop it clo≈øe, if ye ≈øee it be come, put therein ≈øome of your cloth that ye would dye, and turne it well therein, then wring it out, and let it re≈øt 2 or 3 houres: theÃÑ put in agayn your cloth, and v≈øe it as afore≈øayd, & ≈øo ≈øtop it well agayn, and let it re≈øt ≈øo, two or three houres, til ye ≈øhall ≈øee the dye begin to come, & the flower to lie aboue, & to euery going ye ye go thereto, ≈øee if the colour be greene ynough, or waxe greene, and when ye ≈øhall ≈øee it ≈øo, ye ≈øhal ≈øcom of the flower with a di≈øh, and then put your cloth agayn therein, ≈øtir it wel, and wring it forth, then ≈øtoppe it agayne wel, and thus ye mu≈øt colour three or foure times a day, Then mu≈øt ye take the dye in the de≈ø≈øell, and hang it ouer the fire agayne, and there let it be hote, and putte therein two pound and a halfe of a≈øhes. Then put it in the Fatte, and ≈øo lette it re≈øt, but ≈øtoppe it well and clo≈øe, ≈øo let it re≈øt a night, but ≈øtirre it once in the nighte with a ≈øtaffe, and ≈øee in the morning if the dye be come, as afore≈øayd, and ≈øo put in your cloth agayne, but lette it not lye therein too long, that it coole not the dye, and as yee
haue thus dyed it foure times. TheÃÑ ≈øhal ye make it hote agayne ouer the fyre, putting therein two pound of pot a≈øhes, and ≈øo let re≈øt all a might, and ≈øtirre one in the nighte as afore≈øayde, and ≈øtoppe it clo≈øe, and when ye goe thereto, ≈øee if the dye be come, if it be come, ye may dye, as before, that ye thinke good, and when your colour waxe a fayre greene, then is your dye good and rype, and the flowers will lye fayre aboue, but as it beginnes to waxe yelowe, then it is too rype. Then mu≈øt yee put in more cloth.

div.head: How to dye a fayre Linnen with bra≈øill.
div.p:
Ye ≈øhall take ≈øo much linnen as ye will, and to euerye elle of linnen, take two ounces of gall nottes, or xii. nots, the≈øe nots ye ≈øhall breake in two or three peeces, then put them in a kettle with water, and let them ≈øeeth together, and as they haue ≈øod a quarter of an houre or le≈ø≈øe, take it of the fyre, and take your cloth forth thereof, and let it a little ≈øoke by, but let it not drye. As ye haue thus ≈øod it, ye ≈øhall take another Kettle with fayre water, and put it ouer the fire, and make it ≈øeething hote, Then ≈øhall ye to euery elle of cloth, take two ounces of Allum, which yee ≈øhall put in the ≈øayde water, and as it is melted, yee ≈øhall take the fore≈øayd cloth, and put it into the ≈øayde kettle to the Allum, & let it ≈øeeth together, a quarter of an houre, then take forth of the kettle, and wring it a little, then hang it to drye a little, but not too muche. Then mu≈øt yee haue your ≈øod bra≈øill as thus: yee ≈øhall take lye made of wood a≈øhes, but ≈øee it be not too ≈øtrong. And thereof ≈øo much in your panne as will make your cloth weat, then put your bra≈øill in the panne with the lye, and ≈øo lette it ≈øeeth a quarter of an houre, then ≈øet it from the fyre, and haue ready an earthen panne, and by and by, put your lycor & bra≈øiil therein, then ≈øhall ye put your fore≈øayde cloth
therein, ≈øtyrre and turne it well therein, but ≈øee that it be not too drye of the ≈øayd Allum that it hath bene ≈øod with. Al≈øo to foure gallons of lye, ye ≈øhall put le≈ø≈øe then halfe a pound of bra≈øill poulder ≈ømall beaten.

div.head: To make a fayre bra≈øill colour, to worke on cloth or paper.
div.p: Ye ≈øhall take a fayre potte, and put therein a pounde of chalke ≈ømall broken, and put thereto a pottle of good Vineger, and ≈øtirre it well togither. Then let it ≈øtand a daye and a night, then poure the cleare≈øt into a fayre panne, and ≈øee that no chalke go therein, then take two partes of the ≈øayd lye, and put it in a fayre pot, and ≈øet it ouer the fyre, and ≈øeeth it fiue pater no≈øter long, then take it from the fyre, and put the lycor in to fayre a panne, and ye ≈øhall put thereto xiiii. ounces of alluÃÑ, and ≈øtirre it wel with a ≈øtaffe, then take the other part, & put it to the ≈øayd bra≈øill wood, the which ye haue changed, and let it there ≈øeeth, as afore ≈øayd, and put that licor into another panne, and put thereto xiii ounces of Allum, which ye ≈øhall ≈øtirre ≈øo well as afore≈øayd, and when ye haue to≈øt it long, put it then to the other, and ≈øtirre it well, as ye will haue it drye take a pan and fill it full and ≈øet it in the winde eight dayes or more, and there let it drye, & as it is fayre, ye may worke therewith.

div.head: Blue Buckeram to dye.
div.p:
Take three pound of gruis of Turwin, ≈øo calde in dutche, and a pound of Mede, a pound of Floray, and to three pound of Sope a≈øhes, take lx. quartes of water, fir≈øt ye ≈øhall put your Floray into a fayre fatte, and put thereto tenne quartes of water, and ≈øtirre it well altogither, this mu≈øt be ≈øo hote that ye cannot ≈øuffer your hand therein,
in the other water ye ≈øhall put the gruis, with the a≈øhes and Mede, and that put together, and ≈øo ≈øtand, which ye ≈øhal ≈øtir xii. houres long, and waxing a blue, ≈øo ye may worke with it. If it be not blue ynough, ≈øo let it ≈øtand couerd, xx. houres long.

div.head: A red to dye with Crampmede.
div.p: Take a pound of crampmede, to three elles of linnen, & take a fayre pot with water, and ≈øet it by the fire till it be ready to ≈øeeth, and put therein two ounces of gals, and let them ≈øo ≈øeeth together, and then put your linnen therein, and take it ≈øometimes out and in, and at eche time wring it well out. Then take a fayre pot with fayre water, and make it ≈øeething hote, then put therein an ounce of AlluÃÑ, and ≈øo let it ≈øeeth wel, then put your cloth in as afore≈øaid. Then take another pot of water, and let it ≈øeeth therein til it be red, then take that cloth out, and clen≈øe it al about with a cloth. If ye will haue it more darker then mu≈øt yt haue a lye of vnquenched chalke, with the lyke dye: men with woad a≈øhes do make a red dye or colour, without vnqueÃÑched lime, in hauing woad a≈øhes in ≈øtede of vnqueÃÑched lime.

div.head: To dye blacke Veluet or linnen.
div.p: Take of galles and coperas, & ≈øeeth them together, and put your linnen therein, if it be gray ≈øilke, then take of elder barks, and olde yron, and put all in a hearing barrell or ve≈ø≈øel. Then take gruis or ≈øwarfe, this ≈øhal be a thurden dele of the fat, the other two parts ≈øhal be fayre water ≈øo let it ≈øtand three weekes long, & ≈øo ≈øtirre it often wel about, and put your gray ≈øilke therein, and as this is done, ≈øo ≈øhall ye hang it to dry, and ≈øo put it in agayn, ≈øo often til that it be black ynough. In ≈øteede of galles ye maye take harkes of Oke, and ≈øhoemakers blacke.

div.head: To make gray flore.
div.p: Take flore and lay it to ≈øoke 24 houres, then wring it out thorow a cloth, then take lye of wyne a≈øhes, & ≈øpread it 2 houres long on a fayre table, then take the ≈øayd lye, and put it in three ve≈ø≈øels, and take the Flore & put it into one of the ve≈ø≈øels, Then put it wel forth, then put that Flore in the lea≈øt ve≈ø≈øell, then ≈øo in the midde≈øt, and in the fir≈øte, but eare ye put the linnen therin, put in vineger & wring it out.

div.head: To dye ≈øilke red.
div.p: Take of good wood a≈øhes, & make a good lye therof, & put therin of willow or facet woad, & barbary wood or yelow wood, & ≈øoke them therin an houre, then ≈øeeth a quarter of an houre, then put your cloth therein, & put in a little ≈øpani≈øh greene, but that cloth ye mu≈øt fir≈øt allum it.

div.head: To make a black water to dye with.
div.p: A blacke water to dye all maner of ≈øilke clothes, ye ≈øhall take halfe a pound of gall nots, and put thereto ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe then a pottle of water, and an ounce of ≈øwarfe of the grind≈øtone, and a good deale of the fylings of yron, make it ≈øeeth, and put thereto a quarter of a pound of coperas, and ≈øeeth all to the halfe, and put therein a pounde of guÃÑme arabic, then ≈øeeth it till al the gumme be melted. Then ≈øet it from the fire, the older it is the better it wil be.

div.head: ¬∂ To make a thicke water to worke on yealow ≈øilke.
div.p:
Take a pottle of the be≈øt vernice ye can, & put in an ounce of brim≈øtone in fine poulder, & half an ounce of Camphyer,
then ≈øeeth it a while, and let it coole, then ≈øtrayne it thorow a cloth, al≈øo with this ye ≈øhal worke thinne, and this mu≈øt be ≈øod with the fourth part of gumme Arabic.

div.head: To worke on yealow ≈øilke, white, gray or azure colour.
div.p: Take a pottle of Conduite water, and a fourth part of Ar≈øenicke in poulder, and two ladle full of woad, cut the woad in ≈ømall peeces, and make it ≈øeeth as hering, that is ≈øoftly, then ≈øet it from the fyre, and put therein ≈øo much of graynes, as ye put in porrage, and herein al≈øo ye ≈øhall put in of gumme of Arraby, ≈øo much as you ≈øhall ≈øeeme good.

div.head: To make a red water.
div.p: Take a pottle of fayre water, and a fourth parte of gumme, and halfe a pot of faucet woad (≈øo cald in dutche) and then ≈øeeth it together till three pintes be con≈øumed, then ≈øet it from the fyre, and herein yee ≈øhall put halfe an ounce of ≈øpani≈øh greene, and then put in al≈øo of graynes, ≈øo much as ye doe in ≈øea≈øoning your pottage.

div.head: To make a red with bra≈øill.
div.p: Take your Linnen to one pound, take a fourth part of Allum, but fir≈øt ≈øeeeth allum, then laye your linnen therein the ≈øpace of two houres, then take of beaten galles, and put water thereto, then lay your linnen therein, and put in a quarter of a pounde of bra≈øill, and an ounce of gumme of Arabie. Then let it ≈øeeth a fourth part in, and then put in your Linnen. If you will haue it a redde, then put in no galles.

div.head: To make a red water for white ≈øilke or woollen, greene, yealow, violet or azure.
div.p: Take a pottle of running water, and an ounce of bra≈øill, ≈øeeth the≈øe till the halfe be con≈øumed. Then take it from the fyre, and put in ≈øo many graynes, as ye put vnto a pot of porage, and a fourth part of gumme. But if ye wil make it a light red, put it into another fat, whereas there is a quarter of a pound of Allum made in poulder, and ≈øo let it re≈øt all a night and it will do well.

div.head: To make a blew.
div.p: Take three partes of Sope a≈øhes, and one parte of vnquenched lyme, and make a lye thereof, and then lette it cleare, then ≈øtrayne it thorow a thicke cloth, and yee ≈øhall take xv. quartes of the ≈øayd lye, and put thereto a pounde of Bloemen (≈øo calde in dutche) then ≈øtyrre it all well together with a ≈øtaffe, and warme it ouer the fyre, ≈øo that ye may not ≈øcant ≈øuffer your hande therein, but fir≈øte your cloth mu≈øt be ≈øod in Allum, and al≈øo dryed, then put it in the warme dye, two or three tymes, then after, if yee will haue it black or light colour, ≈øo ye may v≈øe it, but before all things your dye mu≈øt be warmed, ere ye dye or colour therewith.

div.head: To make a fayre ≈øanguine dye.
div.p:
Take vpon eche elle of linnen, ≈øixe galles beaten into poulder, and then take three gallons of water put into a tubbe, and put the poulder of the galles thereto, & ≈øturre them well togither, then laye your linnen therein, and turne and wend it well. Then take and wring it drye out, then let it lye therein agayne two houres long, but at ech
houre ye mu≈øt wring it, as before, and lay it therein again in the tubbe, and as it hath layne two houres, & ≈øo wrong out, then take one ounce of Allum, of the be≈øt, and three gallons of water in a Kettle, and make it well and hote redy to ≈øeeth, till all be well molten, then ≈øet it from the fire, and put your linnen therein, & do it as ye haue done before agayne two houres long, then after that take a panne, and put therein two gallons of water, and warme that lyke the other, then take three ounces of bra≈øil and ca≈øt it therein, agayne let it ≈øeeth a quarter of an houre, then take a good quart of water, and ca≈øt it therein ≈øeething, and take a quart of that dye, and lay your linnen therein ≈øix or vii. pater no≈øters long, ≈øo that the dye be dronke all in ye ≈øayde cloth, then wring it forth and handle it well, then laye the cloth agayne in that dye, to≈ø≈øe it, and turne it and wend it well therein, and let it lye ≈øo long therin as afore≈øayd, and ≈øo wring it out, then take the thyrd colour and lay it therin, and let it lye therin a quarter of an houre, and ≈øo it wil be well.

div.head: A light red dye for ≈økinnes.
div.p:
To dye a fayre light red, take xiiii. drye ≈økins as they come from Antwerp, and put them in the riuer, or in water two dayes, and two nights, then take them out of the ≈øayd water, and put into a fat, a Kettle full of vnquenched lyme or chalke, and put ≈øo muche water thereto, as the felles maye well be couered therein, then ≈øturre them wel with a ≈øtaffe altogether, and put your felles therein, then turne and to≈ø≈øe them well, if it be in the ≈øommer, it ≈øhall be ynough to lye therein viii. dayes, & ye mu≈øt ech ii. dayes ≈øee vnto them, if it be in the winter, they mu≈øt lye therein a moneth, then take your felles out, and hang them again in the fore≈øaid riuers or water thre dayes, & three nights, then after wa≈øhe them well in a tubbe with luke warme
water, and ≈øtampe them with your feete, then after wa≈øh them agayne in the riuer water as afore≈øayd, and hang a Kettle ouer the fyre with fayre water, and therin put iiii. pound of Allum, and when it is molten in the water, ≈øeething hot, putting in ≈øo much water that it may be no hoter but your haÃÑd may ≈øuffer therin without ≈øcalding, then ≈øet it from the fyre and put your felles therein, and ≈øtirre them well with your hand, ≈øo let it re≈øt a day and a night, but as ye go to bed you ≈øhall ≈øturre them once wel, then after take your felles forth, and wring the water well out, & as your felles do waxe ≈øomewhat drye, ye mu≈øt weat them agayne: then take foure pottles of pi≈ø≈øe, that is ≈øtale, hang it ouer the fyre in a pan, let it ≈øeeth well, & ≈øcum it cleane ≈øo long as any ≈øcum will ri≈øe, then put in a pot full of beaten lacke, and let it therein ≈øeeth a little, and put therein ≈øo much Allum as a ha≈øel nutte, and giue it therewith a boyling, then ≈øet it from the fyre, and let it ≈øo re≈øt till it be cold to ≈øuffer your hand therein, then put a gla≈ø≈øe ful therof in your felles which be readie ≈øowd like a ≈øack, & holde it too aboue, & with your other hand hold vnder, and ≈øhake it vp and down as ye would bolt meale, do thus ≈øo long til the colour hath wel taken the leather, then turn your fels about, but if it be faire ynough let it ≈øo be, if it be not faire ynough, put of your ≈øayd ≈øub≈øtaunce againe another halfe gla≈ø≈øe therein, and ≈øtirre it about as before, and then rippe your felles, and hang them to drye in ≈øome hye lofte. And as they be drye, ≈øo take and lay them a night in a fat with water, and next day taw them on a ≈øharpe tawing yron, vntill they be all workemanly done, then they are well.

div.head: To make leather red.
div.p:
Take an ouÃÑce of Allum & melt it in a gallon of water, theÃÑ take a calues felle & ≈øpreade it on a rame, ≈øo it mu≈øt be rubbed al ouer with allum water fir≈øt, then incoÃÑtinent ye ≈øhal
≈øtrike it all ouer with bra≈øill water, and let it ≈øo drye in, and then ≈øtrike it all ouer agayne, and ≈øo let it drye in like, but the colour or dye mu≈øt be made warme alwaies, when ye rub thereon. But fyr≈øt ye mu≈øt make it weat with cold water, and wring it agayne out, and then ≈øtretche it forth on a bord, and ≈øo ye may v≈øe it.

The fore≈øayd bra≈øill water, ye ≈øhall make thus. Take three gallons of rayne water, and put therein foure ounces of bra≈øill woad made in poulder, and halfe an ounce of Wey a≈øhes, calde ≈øope a≈øhes, with a little ≈øaffron. Then ≈øeeth it ≈øo long till the third part be wa≈øted. Then clean≈øe that out, and the pot with rayne water againe, and let the halfe ≈øeeth away. Then is the ≈øtrength all out, and with this la≈øt water ye ≈øhall colour fir≈øt, and with the fir≈øt water ye ≈øhall dye or colour la≈øt.

div.head: To dye red felles.
div.p: To dye red Leather, ye ≈øhall ≈øeeth Lack in bene ≈øtraw, and a cur≈øy pi≈ø≈øe, as afore≈øayd is. Then put therin ≈øo much as two great beanes, and then take an ounce of bra≈øil water, and ≈øo let them ≈øeeth together.

div.head: To dre≈ø≈øe Felles with golde.
div.p: To dre≈ø≈øe Felles with golde, take broune red, & grinde it on a ≈øtone, with water mixt with chalke, and lyme water, and therewith you ≈øhall ≈øtrike your felles twi≈øe ouer, then lay your ≈øiluer or golde thereon, and let it drye, then ≈øhall ye ≈ømoothe it with a tooth, and ≈øo ≈øtrike it ouer, and then drye it in the ≈øunne.

div.head: To colour greene Felles.
div.p:
To colour green felles, take ≈øpani≈øh greene, and grind
it vpon a ≈øtone with wine Vineger, and ≈øome ≈øaffron temper this with gumme water and lyme, and ≈øo ≈øtrike youre ≈økinnes therewith.

div.head: To gylde on leather.
div.p: Ye ≈øhall ouer≈øtrike your leather thri≈øe with whites of egges, and gumme water, then lay your gold thereon, and lick it well and fayre, or the yolkes of harde ro≈øted egges, mixt with gum water and ground, the red and the graye ≈økinnes ye may verni≈øh them, take a flat ba≈øon, and put fire vnder, and ≈øpred the felles thereon, and ≈øtrike varni≈øhe al≈øo ouer the ≈økinnes, where it is coloured, but afore you ≈øtrike your felles ≈øtrike it warme on the Ba≈øon, and then let it drye, then ≈ømooth the colour all ouer euen, and when it is drie; then licke it, or burni≈øh it with a tooth, and as ye will haue it fayre, ≈øo take an end of a tallowe candle, and rub it on your arme from the hand to the elbowe, then ≈øtrike it all ouer with that parte of your arme, and it is done.

div.head: Agayne to colour leather red.
div.p: Take the dye for a red leather, and take an ounce of bra≈øill, in a nealed pot, and ≈øeeth it till the third part be wa≈øted, but fir≈øt wa≈øhe your leather in Allum water, or in other water, but lette it not lye long therein, ≈øo lette it drye, and put it therein, and let it re≈øt two dayes and two nightes on a tack, and then hang that leather in the ayre to drye.
If ye will haue it ≈øanguine, take of vyne braunches a≈øhes, and make lye thereof, and with this lye, ≈øeeth your bra≈øill woad, and ≈øo ye may colour red therewith.

div.head: To colour leather greene.
div.p: Take an ounce of Equi≈øetam, in Engli≈øh hor≈øetayle, it is an hearbe growing in low places or medowes, put ther to of olde ≈øtanding water, with a quantitie of Allum pouder, with a little copero≈øe beate in poulder, ≈øo v≈øe it.

div.head: To culler a blue leather.
div.p: Fir≈øt you ≈øhal take an ounce of Endix, ≈øo calde in duche, with one ounce of chalke, and a pottle of Vineger, or good ≈øharpe lye, then put all into a ba≈øon, and there ≈ølyrre it all well together, fir≈øt your felles mu≈øt be made redy thereto, as afore is declared, then put your ≈øtuffe thereon, and ≈øo v≈øe it as the other, and it wil ≈øhew a fayre blue element colour.

div.head: To make a fayre red colour.
div.p: Take your leather which is allumde before, then take of olde pi≈ø≈øe, of ≈øuch as v≈øe to drinke much wyne, and let it ≈øtand til it ≈øtinke, then take the cleare≈øt thereof, and ≈øeeth it til the half be wa≈øted, then take two ounce of lack, with one part of bra≈øill, a part of Allum, & a part of Salarmoniacum, beate them altogether, and put them into a pot, and ≈øet it ouer the fire, and ≈øtir it wel with a white ≈øtick, vntill the ≈øtick waxe red as blood, then take it off, & colour therwith luke warme.

div.head: Another fine red colour.
div.p:
Take halfe an ounce of bra≈øill poulder, and half a pottle of old water, ≈øeeth them together, and ≈øcum it well, then take a little alluÃÑ, which mu≈øt be fir≈øt kild in clay, fir≈øt take
it from the fyre, and then put in your ≈øaid allum, ≈øo re≈øerue it, and v≈øe it as the other.

div.head: To make a light blue colour.
div.p: Take the flowers of the blue bottles among corne, and pick them off, then grynde them on a ≈øtone or morter, and put therevnto a little viniger, then temper it with allum as afore≈øayd, ≈øo ≈øhall ye haue a fayre blue colour, ≈øo may ye v≈øe it incontinent for it will not la≈øt long but chaunge colour.

div.head: To make a white leather blue.
div.p: Take hengarten be≈øien, ≈øo calde in dutche, which I take to be the low elder, calde Dane worte, ≈øeeth the ≈øayde berries in water, then with your hande ≈øtyrre them well about, and al≈øo breake them, ≈øo done, then ≈øeeth it agayne a while, and ≈øo let it coole, and being warme, ≈øtrike all ouer your leather once or twy≈øe, or as ofte as ye ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe, then take of Endir, ≈øo calde in duche, and ≈øtrewe of that pouder thereon, and rub it in, and ≈øo it wil do well.

div.head: Another way for red leather.
div.p: To make your red, take a pound of Mo≈øherumps with a little of vnquenched lyme, then put thereto a pottle of water, and let it ≈øtande a night, then take two partes of other fayre water, and a thirde part of chalke water, with a quantitie of bra≈øill, then put all the ≈øayde ≈øtuffe into a leaden pot, and let it ≈øeeth till the halfe be con≈øumed, then it will be well, and ye may v≈øe it as the other.

div.head: To make a greene colour.
div.p: Take the leaues of an hearbe calde night ≈øhade, then ≈øtampe or beate it in a morter of ≈øtone, ≈øo temper it with Allum, and ≈øo colour your ≈økinnes therewith, al≈øo ye may take of the greene berries of the greene bery tree (which the paynters v≈øe) ≈øtampe them and ≈øo let them re≈øt ten or twelue dayes, then ≈øtrayne them, and put Allum water thereto, and ≈øtrike your ≈økin therewith, but fir≈øte make it warme, and ≈øo v≈øe it.

div.head: Another good greene.
div.p: Take one part of the fore≈øayd lowe elder berryes, and ≈øeeth them in ≈øufficient water, then put therein two ounces of bra≈øill poulder, and an ounce of walkers claye, with a pottle of olde water, let al the≈øe ≈øeeth a good while together, then put in your beaten allum, but not afore, ≈øo ≈øhall it be a fayre colour as the other.
If ye will haue it a more darker colour: ye mu≈øt therewith ≈øtrike twi≈øe all ouer your ≈økinnes: to haue it a lighter colour, then ye ≈øhall mingle it with olde rayne water, and ≈øo v≈øe it.

div.head: To colour blacke Leather after the order in Germanye.
div.p:
To colour leather black, take a herring barrell, and lay it three fingers thicke in the bottome with elder barkes, then take the filinges of yron, and ≈øtrawe it all ouer the ≈øayde barkes, then take as much barke of elder agayne, and lay it therein, and ≈øo likewi≈øe your filings thereon as before. Doe thus, till the ≈øayd barrell be three quarters filde, and hath taken to the quantitie of foure pottels, or
more of the fylinges, then take ≈øo much of rayne water as will fill it vp to couer it all ouer, ≈øo let it ≈øtand a month or that ye doe colour therewith, and euer as it waxeth emptye, fill it vp agayne with filinges, and rayne water as before, in letting it ≈øtande (≈øo filde) a month after, and alwayes let the la≈øt couer be the fillings aboue, and when ye li≈øt to colour therewith, vnto three pottles of colour, ye mu≈øt haue iiii. ounces of beaten galles, and two ounces of coperas water, then let it ≈øeeth together before yee dye, that ye may coulour the better therewith: thus y√©e may v≈øe it at your plea≈øure.

div.head: To colour a white leather.
div.p: Fir≈øt take your ≈økinnes and hang them in lyme water, till they waxe ≈øupple, or in chalke water, and when they be well ≈øoked, if ye will make ha≈øt of them, fir≈øt take of the heere, and clen≈øe it out of the ≈øayde water, ≈øo that all the ≈øub≈øtaunce afore≈øayd be taken forth of the felles, and being clen≈øed then a day or more, then wring the ≈øayde water all cleane forth, and let them drye, and to vi. felles put not aboue two ounces of Allum, and lette your felles lye therein a nighte and a daye, then wring them and drawe them well vntill they be all cleane, and then v≈øe them.

div.head: Another fayre red colour.
div.p:
Take a felle or felles, and weate them in Allum water and ≈øalt mingled together, and to iiii. ounces of ≈øalt, take viii. ounce of Allum to the weating of your ≈øayde felles, and al≈øo two ounces of lyme, then ≈øeeth all in two pottles of rayne water, then ≈øtrayne it thorow a linnen cloth, and wa≈øh therewith what fell ye will, then ≈øpreade it abroade on the earth, and take a woollen cloth, and with the ≈øame
lycor, ≈øtrike the ≈øayd felles all ouer, and ≈øo let them drye. Then they will be ready for to receyue your colour, then after that take at the lea≈øt foure ounces of the lycor of the la≈øt end of a brewing, with two ounces of bra≈øill poulder, then ≈øeeth all the≈øe in two pottles of the lye of ≈øope a≈øhes, with one ounce of Allum, and when it is well ≈øod, take it of the fyre, and all to ≈øtrike your felles therewith, and theÃÑ let it drye, and ≈øo they ≈øhall be ready and ≈øoft withall, and here yee mu≈øte vnder≈øtande with what colours yee ≈øhall ≈øtrike your felles withall, which is, with the red, and with blue, and al≈øo greene, for the≈øe ≈øhall chieflye abide and not go off, al≈øo to weat your felles, where linnen yearne hath bene ≈øoked in, it will be likewi≈øe very good.

div.head: To colour a black ≈øpani≈øh leather.
div.p:
