Take of Pomplemelc, ≈øo calde in dutche, and make it warme, then wa≈øhe your felles therewith till the whyte come no more off, neyther forth thereof, and to a ≈ømall fell ye ≈øhall take foure ounces of Venis tot appelen, ≈øo calde in dutche, then beate it a little into peeces, and ca≈øt of fayre water thereon, and ≈øeeth it till it waxe ≈øoft, ≈øo that ye may wring it betwixt your hands, then ≈øtrayne out the water thereof, if it be too hote, take a broade earthen panne, and put the ≈øayd licor therein, then ≈øpread your ≈økinne abrode and dip your felle therein till it be well weat, doe it ≈øo iii. or iiii. times, then take good ≈øhoemakers colour, or black, ≈øo much as ye ≈øhal think good, the which ye ≈øhal make the fell thorow moy≈øt withal, & put thereto a little vitrial coporas, then wring it wel forth, & lay it together, and let it dry ≈øoftly, then take it or it be thorow drye, and wring it between your hands, for ≈øo it will be ≈øoft, do ≈øo ofteÃÑ times and when it is drye, take of Goo≈øe greace, or hogs greace in a woollen cloth, and rub it therewith too and fro a good ≈øpace before a fyre, or by a hote ouen, ≈øo rub and chafe it
well in with your hands, that the greace be not ≈øeene, Of both, Goo≈øe grea≈øe is the better, then Lin≈øeede oyle, or ≈øhoemakers trayne.

div.head: Another way for black leather.
div.p: To make a black leather, be it ≈øheepe or other. Fir≈øt take your leather and ≈øtretche it, then ≈øprinckle it well oute of your mouth with water, then take your tawing ≈øtocke, & taw it well therewith, al≈øo rub and chafe it together with your hands as ≈øhomakers do, & draw it well with your paring yron, theÃÑ put it on your dre≈ø≈øing bord, & ≈øtrike it with a woollen cloth til it be al euen, & then ye may colour it, & when it is well coloured, then wring the ≈øayd colour oute of your ≈økinnes, ≈øo put it in agayne into the ≈øayde colour, & ≈øo do as ye did before, at the fir≈øt time it mu≈øt bee alwaye twi≈øe coloured, then hang it in the ≈øunne and let it drye, then ye ≈øhal take it agayne, not being thorow drye, rubbe it, and ≈øo colour it agayne, as before. If yee haue it verye ≈øoft: rubbe and chafe it betwixt your handes, euer before ye colour it, ≈øo being well dyed and coloured, which at the lea≈øt mu≈øt be v. or vi. times ouer. Thus yee mu≈øte doe for ≈øheepe ≈økinnes, which al≈øo mu≈øt be dre≈øt with allum, and when ye lay your colour on them, then take lyn≈øeede oyle, and with a woollen cloth, ≈øtrike your dre≈ø≈øing yron therewith, and when your ≈økinnes be thereon well tawde, then take of your ≈øleight colour or dye out of your fatte al cold, and coloure your ≈økinne therewith once after your ≈øayde lin≈øeede oyle. Then put it together, and wring foorth the oyle and greace therein, and the colour al≈øo, and being wel wrong out, lay it together, and colour it once againe, and being thus coloured three tymes ouer, then take and drye it, and ≈øo it is done.

div.head: To gilde on Leather.
div.p: Fir≈øt ye mu≈øt worke it well, and ouer≈øtrike it with the whytes of egges, and gum water beaten togeather, then lay your gold thereon, and ≈øtrike it well, ye maye temper therewith hard yeolks of egges beaten with gum water. The redde and greene ≈økinnes ye may verni≈øh, as to take a ba≈øon with a ≈ømoothe bottome, and put coles vnder, and then laye, and ≈øpread your ≈økinne thereon, ≈øo ≈øtrike youre ≈økinne all ouer with verni≈øh, but afore ye ≈øtrike it ouer (on the bottome of the ba≈øon or pan) yee ≈øhall fir≈øte rubbe and warme your ≈økinne all ouer on the ba≈øons bottome, then ≈øtrike your colour all ouer thereon, and ≈øo let it drye, and being drye, ≈ømooth it with a ≈øleke ≈øtone, and ≈øo yee ≈øhall make it fayre.

div.head: To make a lye to dye a blue.
div.p:
When ye will dye a blue, ye mu≈øt make a ≈øtrong lye, and ye mu≈øt take twi≈øe ≈øo many a≈øhes with a third part of chalke, then make it ≈øeeth foure paterno≈øter whiles, then ca≈øt thereto of cleane waxe, whiche will make it clarifye the better, then ≈øet it ouer the fire, and let it there ≈øoke two houres or thereabouts, then put into a pan fiue pounde of woad, and put it to the ≈øayd lye, then hang it ouer the fire, and warme it well without ≈øeething, and then put it in ≈øome hearing ve≈ø≈øell, let it remayne there halfe an houre, then ca≈øt therein halfe a pinte of Zemes, ≈øo calde in dutche, and ≈øtirre it well with a ≈øtaffe, then couer it wel the ≈øpace of a quarter of an houre, and then it will be good and redy to dye with, then take of linnen yearne, or woollen cloth, other fu≈øtian or Oyer: to haue it a light blue, put it but once in, and to haue it a little brouner, put it in twy≈øe, and to haue it more browner, put it thri≈øe in, or ≈øo long till ye
≈øee it broune ynough, and when yee haue dyde what yee plea≈øe, let the ve≈ø≈øell re≈øt till another day. If then yee will dye more yearne, linnen or woollen, then mu≈øt the dye be taken out of the ve≈ø≈øell, and put into a kettle, and put therto foure quartes of lye, as is afore≈øayd, ≈øo couer it wel and let it ≈øtande one houre, then put thereto halfe a pounde of grening weede, and hang it ouer the fyre agayne, and let it colour well withoute ≈øeething, then ca≈øt it into the ve≈ø≈øel with a pint of Zemes, and couer it well, and let it re≈øt a quarter of an houre, and then put therein agayne to dye what ye thinke good, and colour it as is afore≈øayde, al≈øo when ye doe ≈øet and prepare your fatte, yee mu≈øt haue to euery ounce of greening weede, one quart of good lye.

div.head: To colour or dye a black.
div.p: Take a ve≈ø≈øell, and put in colde gall water, then laye your fu≈øtian therein, ≈øtyrre it and handle it well therein, and then put it into the black dye, and to≈ø≈øe it and handle it well therein al≈øo, and then agayn in the gall water, and agayne in the dye, doe thus ≈øo often till it bee dyed ynough.

div.head: To dye a fayre yealow colour as Golde.
div.p: Lay fir≈øt your linnen in allum water foure howers loÃÑg, then take one part of chalk, and two parts of wood a≈øhes, then make a lye thereof, and ≈øeeth your dye therewith, al≈øo the be≈øt lye to dye with is, to take two partes of wood a≈øhes, and one part of chalke, worke and v≈øe it as yee ≈øhall perceiue be≈øt.

div.head: To dye Fu≈øtian gray.
div.p: Take of hay a≈øhes, and vyne a≈øhes by them≈øelues, and make a lye thereof, then put your fu≈øtian there in the hay lye, and then in the other lye, do it thus ≈øo long till yee ≈øee it all coloured ynough, with the≈øe and ≈øuch like yee maye dye linnen gray, but yee mu≈øt put thereto a little more of calles.

div.head: To dye blacke ≈øilke or veluet.
div.p: Yee ≈øhall fir≈øte ≈øoke your ≈øilke in gall water an houre long, and then let it drye, then ≈øhall ye laye it in the lye of ≈øaeche meale, (≈øo calde in dutche) and with a≈øhes of vynes, and lay it therein xii. houres or more, then let it drye wel, and after ye mu≈øt ≈øeeth it in black dye two or three times, til that ye thinke it be fayre ynough.

div.head: To dye a ≈øilke that hath lo≈øt his colour.
div.p: Take Satten or Dama≈øke that mu≈øt bee made black, ≈øeeth it fyr≈øt in the dye of Oken barkes, then drye it in the wynde, then ≈øeeth it agayne in your black dye, and ≈øo let it drye alwayes agayne. And if then it be not blacke ynough, ≈øeeth it in gall water and black dye, til it be fayre ynough, ≈øo let it drye, then rub all ouer with butter, or other greace, and wring it well betweene your handes, then ≈øtrike it ouer with a fayre woolen cloth, and it ≈øo wil be wel.

div.head: To make a gray Fu≈øtian.
div.p:
Fir≈øt lay your Fu≈øtian to ≈øoke the ≈øpace of iii. houres,
then to viii. elles of Fu≈øtian, take two ounces of broken galles, and put them into warm water, then put your gal water into another fatte, with eyght quartes of fre≈øh water, then lay your fu≈øtian therein, & ≈øtirre it wel with your handes therein, to≈ø≈øe it wel, & wring it forth wel, & laye it therein agayn one houre, & ≈øo wring it wel forth, then put it into the black dye, and lay it therein another houre, ≈øo wring it wel, then ≈øcoure it in the fayre riuer water, and then hang it to drye if then it be not gray ynough, ≈øoke it agayne in fayre water, and then put into your gall water, and then the black dye, then ≈øcoure it and drye it, ≈øo burle it and dre≈ø≈øe it vp, and ≈øo it is done.

div.head: Black ≈øilke to dye.
div.p: To one pound of ≈øilke, take xii. gall nots beaten into a fyne poulder, then ≈øeeth that ≈øilke with the galles in commen water, halfe an houre long, then take of your blacke dye, and ≈øeeth it therein another halfe houre, then take it forth, and let it coole, and then put it agayne into the dye, and let it ≈øeeth therein another halfe houre, if then it bee not fayre ynough, ≈øeeth it therein, til it be fayre, then take and wa≈øhe it out of that colour and hang it to drye, and ≈øo it is done.

div.head: To colour curried ≈økinnes greene, or felles to couer Bookes.
div.p:
Take the buds of white & black thorn, which ye mu≈øt gather in the moneth of Augu≈øt, when they beginne to waxe rype and blacke, put them in a well leaded pot, the ≈øpace of tenne dayes, then put thereto foure ounces of Allum, & boyle them together well, then putte it into a poudring ve≈ø≈øell of Beefe or Porke, and clo≈øe it well that it take no
wynd, then ≈øet it a little in the ≈øunne, and when ye would colour therewith, take a little of the ≈øayd coloure, & myxe it with ≈øome lye, and warme it, and then ≈øtrike it on the ≈økinnes, and ye ≈øhal ≈øee a fayre colour. Al≈øo take Lincaile, or canker of Latine, hony, and mixe them together in like, and put thereto pi≈ø≈øe, ≈øo much that it may take colour, and al≈øo ≈øtayne the ≈økinne, and then drye it in the ≈øhade.

div.head: To make a yealow colour on ≈økinnes.
div.p: Take the rype ≈øeedes of Nerprun, ≈øo cald in french, dry them in the ≈øunne, and when yee will worke therewith, temper it with lye, and with a little allum of the Rocke, and let it re≈øt till it be molten, the whiche will make it to take a yealow coloure, but the lye mu≈øte fir≈øte bee heate a little.

div.head: To dye thread blacke.
div.p: Take a quantitie of broken or bru≈øed galles, and boyle them in water in a ≈ømall potte, and when they haue a little boylde, take out all the galles, and put into the ≈øame pot ≈ø√≥ much Copero≈øe as ye haue had of galles, and put therewith a little gumme of Arabye, and then giue it agayne another boyling, ≈øo let it boyle a little, and with the ≈øayd dye, yee ≈øhall colour therein your threed, then take it forth, and ye ≈øhall ≈øee it a fayre ≈øhining black.

div.head: To dye thread gray.
div.p: Take of the ≈øayd black dye, ≈øo much as ye li≈øt, and put therevnto halfe ≈øo much water, more or le≈ø≈øe as yee will haue your colour deepe or light. Then boyle your threade therein, and you ≈øhal haue it gray as ye li≈øt, other browne or lighter, other after a mou≈øe dunne.

div.p: Take the barkes of Pomgranads, & the pilles of dryde Oranges, then boyle them in water with a little Allum, as great as a ≈ømall nutte, then let it coole, and when it is colde, put your thread therein, and boyle it agayne, and ye ≈øhal haue a fayre colour.

div.head: For to currie a raw Gote≈økinne.
div.p: Take a gotes ≈økinne raw, and put it in warme water, and let it re≈øt there a day, then ≈øcrape and clean≈øe it very cleane, and take away all the fylth thereof, and to fini≈øhe it, take water, and ≈øet it ouer the fyre, and put therein a handfull of fatte, and foure ounces of roche Allum, then ≈øtyrre all together til it begin to boyle, then ≈øet it from the fyre, and let it re≈øt til it be cold, then take an egge, and beate it with a little Oile oliue, this done put your gotes felle in the ≈øayd water, and ≈øtirre it well al aboute with your handes three or foure times, and ≈øo it ≈øhal be in good ca≈øe and wel curried.

div.head: To dye ≈økinnes in a blue like azure.
div.p: The wooll being cleane taken off, and the felle wa≈øhed cleane in fayre water, ≈øo wring it al out, then take the beries of the greening tree, as paynters v≈øe, and the berries of elder, ≈øeeth them together in water of Allum, then ≈øtrayne that water, ≈øo let it re≈øt, then poure away the vppermo≈øt, and ≈øtrayne the re≈øt agayne, then let it drye, and wa≈øhe with that cleare water, but ≈øee that your felle bee cleane: then take your colour, and ≈øtrike your felle al ouer therewith being warme, and ≈øo let it drye, ≈øo it will bee a good blue.

div.head: To dye ≈økinnes with Madder, called Kubea tinctorum in Latine.
div.p: Fir≈øt ≈ø√©e that your ≈økinnes be readye wa≈øhed and wrong cleane, and ≈øo layde abroade, then ≈øhall yee weat it all ouer with the lyes of whyte Wyne, wherein baye Salt haue bene boyled, and ≈øo wring foorth that agayne, then take the a≈øhes of the ≈øhelles of Creuis, or Sea crabbes, and temper it with the fore≈øayde water and ≈øalt, and therwith rubbe your ≈økinnes and wa≈øhe them well then with cleare water, and wring him, take ruddle & teÃÑper it with the ≈øayd lies, and rub it al ouer therewith, & ≈øo with ye ≈øaid a≈øhes, thus wa≈øh & wring it three times, if it be not then well, ye ≈øhal giue him a colouring with bra≈øill, and your Madder mixt together with the ≈øaid water or lies, or that ≈øome tartar haue bene ≈øod in, which mu≈øt be made warm, when ye lay your ruddle, ≈øo leaue it a night, then putte on your Madder, mixt with allum or lyes, or allum cativum ≈øtieped in water, al≈øo you may adde vnto it, the ≈øhering of ≈øcarlet takeÃÑ out of the boyling lye, which is al≈øo good.

div.head: A good greene to greene≈økinnes.
div.p:
Take fir≈øt and clean≈øe your ≈økinnes, annoynt and ≈øoke them well in cold water, then take the berries of the ≈øap greening tree, and being rype about Michaelmas, take & ≈øtampe them, and ≈øo let them re≈øt iii. or iiii. dayes, then put therto of rayn water a little, and then boyle them with a ≈øoft fire, in ≈øtyrring them ≈øtill, then if ye will haue it lighte greene, put to but a little allum, & the ≈øadder green put too the more allum in the boyling and boyle it but a little, theÃÑ ye may fold your ≈økinnes in the midde≈øt, and rub him on both ≈øides therewith, and then with a little poulder of allum, then take a≈øhes burnt of ≈øheepes dung, and all ouer

div.head: A ≈øleighter greene with the ≈øappe berrie.
div.p: Let your ≈økinnes be fir≈øt annointed, & wel wa≈øhed, and ≈øo wrong forth, and then ≈øtretch them as the order is, then take of the ≈øame ≈øap berries afore≈øayd, let them be ≈øtampt with roche allum & water, and a little boyld, and therwith giue your ≈økinne a ≈øtroke or two al ouer, & then let it dry, then giue him a colouring with yealow, made of the ≈øayd berries, ≈øod with allum water, and agayne of ≈øaffron, then let it dry√©, and ye ≈øhall ≈øee a fayre colour.

div.p: Your ≈økinnes being annoynted, wa≈øhed and ≈øpread, ye colour him with the fore≈øayd ≈øappe greene, and put vnto it a few weat a≈øhes, and rub the felle al ouer therewith, & being wa≈øhed and wiped agayn, ≈øtrike him ouer with Indian colour, ≈øod with roch allum, then let it dry, theÃÑ ≈øtrike him ouer with the fore≈øayd yealow, and ≈øo ye ≈øhal haue a fayre excellent greene colour.

div.head: To dye a crimo≈øine colour.
div.p:
Scrape hard ≈øope, and ≈øo melt it in commen water, & put your ≈øilk in a linnen or thin canuas bag, and ≈øo put it into the Kettle to the ≈øoped water, & let it boyle ≈øoftly halfe an houre ≈øpace, but ≈øtur it ofte for burning, then wa≈øhe it in ≈øalte water fyr≈øte, and after in fre≈øh water, for ech pound of ≈øilke, take a pound or more of allum, layde ≈øufficyente
in colde water, and therein put your ≈øilk without the bag, and let it re≈øt therein viii. houres, then take and wa≈øhe it in fre≈øh water, then wring it, & put it in the pan to ye crim≈øine colour, being wel ≈øtampt & cleane, take iiii. ounce, and boile it with ≈øo much water as wil couer your ≈øilke foure fingers aboue in water, and to ech pounde of crimo≈øine colour, put too three ounces of galles in fyne pounder, or in ≈øteede thereof yee maye put in halfe an ounce of Ar≈øenic, which is not very whole≈øome becau≈øe of the fume, nor the water thereof, and when it boyleth put in your ≈øilke as afore prepared, & there let it boyle a quarter of an houre, then wring it a little, and drye it in the ≈øhade, and ≈øo it wil be fayre.

div.head: To die a black after the common ≈øort of the countrey women.
div.p: They take ≈øo much water as wil couer the ho≈øe, or other cloth, but fir≈øte they al to ≈øtrike their ho≈øe or cloth, with ≈øwart of the grind≈øtone, then they laye alder pilles fir≈øt in the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øel, & thereon lay your cloth or ho≈øe, and then pilles thereon agayne, then lay your ho≈øe thereon, & pilles thereon agayn, & then couer al with water, ≈øo let them boyle ≈øoftly two haures ≈øpace, and turne your cloth often therein, then ≈øee if it be black ynough, if not, take new ≈øwart, and pilles, and v≈øe them as yee did at the fir≈øt, and ≈øo boyle them agayne til they be black, then ≈øcoure and wa≈øhe them out, and it is done. div.head: How to harden Jron and Steele, and al≈øo to ≈øoften, to ≈øowder, and to gylde.
To make Yron or ≈øteele as fofte as copper.
div.p: TAke a chalk ≈øtone vn≈ølect, with as much allum, fir≈øt ≈øtampe the Allum verye fine in a morter, then take your chalke and mingle therewith, then ≈øpread it half a finger, or a finger thick, on a linnen cloute, and wrap your yron therein, whiche yee would haue ≈øoft, and lay it in the midde≈øt of a fyre, & there let it lye an houre or more, till the fyre is out and bee all cold of him≈øelfe without any other thing done to it. div.p: Another way for the ≈øame, take only a white fyre turffe, and lay your yron or ≈øteele in the midde≈øt thereof, and lay it in the fyre, and let it lye there ≈øo long, til the fyre do go forth, and waxe colde of it ≈øelfe, then take it out, and it ≈øhal be as ≈øoft as neede ≈øhall require.

div.p: Take the water, or the iuyce of Rafany, which I take to be the Rape, then heate your yron hoce, and quenche it therein, and it ≈øhal become ≈øoft agayne.

div.p: Take of Sope a≈øhes, and vn≈ølect lyme, of eyther alyke, then make a lye thereof, whiche lye yee ≈øhall ≈øtrayne nyne tymes thorowe a ≈øtrayner, then take other yron or ≈øteele, and lay it therein one night, and it will be ≈øo ≈øoft ye may ea≈øilye cutte it, will yee then haue it harde agayne, ≈øo quenche it in colde water, and it ≈øhall waxe harde agayne.

div.p: Take the yelow flowers of Marigoldes, with the ≈øtele and blo≈ø≈øome, ≈øtampe the flowers, and ≈øtrayne it thorowe a cloth, and put that iuyce into a pot, then take the yron or ≈øteele that ye will make ≈øoft, and as red hote as yee canne doe ≈øleke it in that iuyce, and it will bee as ≈øofte as Copper.

div.p:
Al≈øo take ≈ølecken and long wormes out of the earth, of eche alike, and a thyrd part of falte, then take an earthen potte, and make it full of holes in the bottome lyke to a ≈øiue, then take the ≈øalt, and ≈øalte the wormes into the pot. Then take another potte, and ≈øet it vnder that pot, then will that ≈øalt melt with the wormes, and runne into the other potte, and that in the vnder potte yee ≈øhall keepe, then lay a ≈øtone on that pot, and make it to ≈øeeth well, and ≈øcumme it ≈øo long as any ≈øcumme will ry≈øe, then take it from the fyre that it may coole, then ≈øcumme that off aboue, then make your ≈øteele red hote as fyre, and ≈øo quenche therein, which yron or ≈øteele a man may bow like as it were copper: then to make it hard, heate it red hote,

div.p: Take an hearbe calde in Latine, Vngula cabellina, it is a clote, cald in Engli≈øh of ≈øome Colts foote, or Buls foote, take and make a water therof, and make your yron redde hote, whiche yee will haue ≈øofte, then quenche it in the ≈øayde water, and it ≈øhall become ≈øofte, that yee maye v≈øe it for your purpo≈øe, and ≈øo harden it agayne as the other.

div.p: Take Slecken ≈øo calde in duche, and ≈øtampe it with ≈øtrong wyne Vineger, then make your yron or ≈øteele red hote, that yee will haue ≈øofte, and quenche it in the ≈øayde iuyce, and then it ≈øhall bee ≈øofte like the other, and to make it harde agayne, wherein to quenche with colde water as before.

div.p: Take of vnquenched lyme, with as much of ≈øope a≈øhes, & thereof ye ≈øhal make a lye after this maner, whiche is, yee ≈øhall ≈øtrayne it thorow a ≈øtrainer ix. times, then take your ≈øteele or cri≈øtall, and lay it a night therein and a daye, ≈øo it ≈øhall be very ≈øoft, if ye will haue it hard agayne, ≈øo quench it in cold water as the other afore≈øayd.

div.p: Take an ounce of Coperas, halfe an ounce of whyte Ar≈øenic, which is calde whyte Orpemente, then make your Coper to runne, and diuide your Ar≈øenicke in two parts, then ca≈øt one part into your copper, and ≈øtir it well all together, and then ca≈øt in the other parte of your Ar≈øenic to your copper, and ≈øtir it wel altogether, ≈øo done, ca≈øt it on a ≈øtone, and ≈øpread it thin, and when it is colde, beate it into a fyne poulder, and v≈øe it likewi≈øe, as the other before mentioned.

div.p: Take one ounce of Orgall, or Orgyrs, in dutch ≈øo named, with a thyrde part of Vermillion, and a fourth parte of Bolearmoniac, with as much of Aquauite, then worke and grinde them altogether on a ≈øtone with lyn≈øeede oyle, ≈øo done: put therevnto ≈øome of the ≈øtone calde Lapis Calaminaris, the bigne≈ø≈øe of a hazel nutte, and grynd therwith in the end, three or foure droppes of Verni≈øh, ≈øo take it off the ≈øtone, and ≈øtrayne it thorow a linnen cloth into a ≈øtone potte, for it mu≈øt bee as thicke as hony, ≈øo keepe it, and ≈øtrike it whereon ye li≈øt, and ≈øo let it dry, and then ye may lay your golde, or ≈øiluer thereon, as afore≈øayd.

div.p:

div.p:

div.p: Take of verdigreace, of Mercury ≈øublyme, of vitriol, & of Allum, of ech a like, then beat them ≈ømal, & ≈øo put it into a gla≈ø≈øe, ≈øo let it ≈øtand half a day, & ≈øtyr it often, then ≈øtrike it al ouer with wax, or yealow lead, mixt with lyn≈øeed oyle, or lii≈øen ≈ømout, ≈øo cald in dutche, and ≈øtrike thereon with ye water in ye gla≈ø≈øe, & let it ≈øtand half a day, but if ye write or lay thin that the water may eate it the ≈øooner, which yee ≈øhal couer al the yron or ≈øteele thin with wax, and to draw theron what ye li≈øt with a pen≈øil in the wax, vnto ye grouÃÑd, then ≈øtrike your water al ouer, and ≈øo it ≈øhal eate on your grauen places, or lay theron Mercury ≈øublimatuÃÑ in your grauen places, and put therevnto vineger, and ≈øo let it re≈øt half an hower after, and it wil do wel.
